THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ann
      Thompson, Claimant, 
				For John
          Michael Harvey, Deceased, Employee, Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Cisson
      Construction Co., Employer and Ohio Casualty Co., Carrier,  Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4339
  Heard January 9, 2008 â€“ Filed February 1, 2008

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Linda B. McKenzie, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Weston Adams, III, George D. Gallagher, and John G. Coggiola, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.: In this workersâ€™
  compensation case, Ann Thompson (Thompson), mother of deceased employee John
  Michael Harvey (Harvey), appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision reversing the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s award of death benefits pursuant to section 42-9-290 of the
  South Carolina Code of Laws.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Harvey sustained a work-related injury to his right knee and back on January 12, 2000.Â  As
  a result of his initial injuries, Harvey later claimed an aggravation of a
  pre-existing psychiatric condition.Â  His employer, Cisson Constuction, and its
  carrier, Ohio Casualty (collectively Cisson) admitted the right knee and back
  injuries and provided temporary disability and medical benefits. Â Cisson denied
  aggravation of the pre-existing psychiatric condition.  
A
  plethora of emotional problems, including substance abuse, depression, anxiety,
  suicide attempts, and multiple hospitalizations characterized Harveyâ€™s medical
  history.Â  Previous medical records indicated a diagnosis of bipolar affective
  disorder.Â  Yet, for approximately four or five years prior to his January 12,
  2000 work accident, Harveyâ€™s emotional status was stable; he had not taken any
  medication for depression and had not attempted suicide during that period.Â  In
  his own words, Harvey averred he â€œwas dealing with it pretty good.â€Â   
Notwithstanding
  numerous evaluations and medical treatments for his compensable injuries, Harvey continued to experience significant pain.Â  Medications, including Oxycontin, were
  prescribed.Â  Harveyâ€™s injuries, combined with the medications, virtually
  immobilized him.Â  Other than taking care of his personal hygiene and
  occasionally preparing a meal for himself, he was able to do very little.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
Harveyâ€™s treating physician, Dr. David Shallcross, noted that â€œdespite being seen by many
  physicians, we have not found anything seriously wrong with this patient to
  explain his pain.â€Â  Medical examination revealed no signs of neurological
  dysfunction, and Harvey was â€œclear to ambulate without any restrictions.â€Â  Dr.
  Shallcross released Harvey at maximum medical improvement with a 5% whole
  person impairment rating and recommended treatment for his pre-existing
  emotional condition, regardless of his physical status.Â   
Harvey began psychiatric treatment with Dr. Mario Galvarino in April of 2001.Â  Dr.
  Galvarino summarized Harveyâ€™s mental state in his initial evaluation:Â  â€œThis
  individual is sad, apprehensive and does nothing at home.Â  He sleeps.Â  He has
  difficulty.Â  He is very angry, apprehensive, irritable, snappy.Â  Concentration
  and memory are poor.Â  He feels hopeless, helpless, useless and very guilty.Â  He
  feels good-for-nothing and wants to die, but he is not actively suicidal.â€Â  Dr.
  Galvarino opined, â€œ[T]he patientâ€™s depression and manic depression have
  considerably and significantly worsened since his injury.â€Â  In May of 2001, Dr.
  Galvarino advised Harveyâ€™s attorney that the injuries he sustained in the
  â€œon-the-job accident with resulting chronic pain and depression have rendered
  him permanently and totally disabled.â€
On
  March 4, 2002, Thompson, Harveyâ€™s mother, found him dead from a drug overdose.Â 
  Pathologist Brett Woodard reported, â€œ[T]he cause of death was Oxycontin over
  dosage.Â  Based on the number of residual pills and pill debris within the
  stomach and the previous psychiatric history of the deceased, the manner of
  death is suicide.â€  
Harvey had moved in to live with Thompson after breaking up with his girlfriend
  approximately nine months prior to his death. Â Thompson sought death benefits
  under section 42-9-290 of the South Carolina Code of Laws, contending Harveyâ€™s death by suicide was the result of emotional trauma or depression secondary to his
  compensable work accident. Â 
The
  single commissioner found, inter alia,:Â  (1) Harveyâ€™s work
  related injury aggravated his pre-existing psychiatric condition; (2) the
  aggravation of the pre-existing psychiatric condition was compensable; (3)
  Harvey reached maximum medical improvement on May 25, 2001, with an impairment
  rating of 25% loss of use to his back and 20% loss of use to his right leg; (4)
  Harveyâ€™s back and right knee injuries, when combined with the severe
  aggravation of his pre-existing emotional problems, rendered himÂ  totally and
  permanently disabled, pursuant to section 42-9-10; (5) Harveyâ€™s death was the
  result of suicide; and (6) the suicide resulted from and was directly linked to
  Harveyâ€™s severe emotional condition brought on by his compensable injuries.Â  The
  single commissioner awarded Thompson death benefits pursuant to sections
  42-9-140 and 42-9-290, including $2500 for burial expenses.Â  The Appellate
  Panel affirmed the single commissioner, with the exception of the award for
  burial expenses.Â   
On
  appeal to the Court of Common Pleas the circuit judge reversed the Appellate
  Panelâ€™s decision as a matter of law, holding: Â â€œCompensation for Claimantâ€™s
  suicide is specifically barred by the plain language of Â§ 42-9-60 because the
  event for which Thompson seeks compensationâ€”Claimantâ€™s death by suicideâ€”was
  occasioned by Claimantâ€™s willful intent to kill himself.â€Â  As an alternate
  ground for reversal, the circuit judge ruled:Â  â€œAs a matter of law, Claimantâ€™s
  intent to kill himself was not negated by a spontaneous or uncontrollable
  impulse, or other mental derangement depriving him of normal judgment negating
  his willful intention;â€ and â€œClaimantâ€™s suicide two years after his work
  related accident is not a â€˜natural consequenceâ€™ flowing from such accident.â€
ISSUES

	
		
			1. 
			Does section 42-9-60 of
  the South Carolina Code of Laws bar death benefits to the deceased
  employeeâ€™s mother when the cause of Â  death was suicide?
 
		
		
			2.
			Was the deceased employeeâ€™s 
			suicide the result of spontaneous, impulsive, or instinctive 
			conduct, without deliberate or formed intention, or without 
			conscious volition to produce death, thus negating his willful 
			intent to kill himself?  
 
		
		
			3.
			Was the employeeâ€™s suicide a 
			â€œnatural consequenceâ€ flowing from  his
  original compensable accident?
		
	

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe
  South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act governs judicial review of a
  decision of the workersâ€™ compensation commission.â€ Â Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc.,
  276 S.C. 130, 134, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981); Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C.
  454, 467, 617 S.E.2d 369, 376 (Ct. App. 2005) cert. dismissed as
    improvidently granted Aug. 2007; Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360
  S.C. 276, 288, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Pursuant to the APA, an
  appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision
  is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Grant
    v. Grant Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 200, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(Supp. 2006).
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Substantial Evidence Standard
The judicial review of the Appellate Panelâ€™s factual findings is
  governed by the substantial evidence standard. Â Gadson v. Mikasa Corp., 368
  S.C. 214, 221, 628 S.E.2d 262, 266 (Ct. App. 2006); Frame v. Resort Servs.,
    Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 527, 593 S.E.2d 491, 494 (Ct. App. 2004); Corbin v.
      Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 94-95 (Ct. App. 2002); Lockridge
        v. Santens of America, Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App.
  2001). Â The Appellate Panelâ€™s decision must be affirmed if supported by
  substantial evidence in the record.Â  Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C.
  435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Sharpe v. Case
    Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999)). Â A reviewing
  court may not substitute its judgment for the judgment of the agency as to the
  weight of the evidence on questions of fact. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(d)(e)(Supp. 2006); see also Hall
    v. United Rentals, Inc., 371 S.C. 69, 77, 636 S.E.2d 876, 881 (Ct. App.
  2006). Â However, a reviewing
  court may reverse or modify a decision of the Appellate Panel if the findings,
  inferences, conclusions, or decisions of the panel are â€œclearly erroneous in
  view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(e)(Supp.
  2006); Bass v. Kenco Group,
  366 S.C. 450, 457, 622 S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 2005); Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App.
  2004) affâ€™d 369 S.C. 176, 631 S.E.2d 899 (2006).Â   
It is
  not within the appellate courtâ€™s province to reverse the Appellate Panelâ€™s
  factual findings if they are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Etheredge
    v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 454, 562 S.E.2d 679, 681 (Ct. App. 2002)
  (citing Hoxit v. Michelin Tire Corp., 304 S.C. 461, 405 S.E.2d 407
  (1991)); Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 282, 519 S.E.2d 583, 591
  (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor
  the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which,
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the
  conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action. Â Pratt
    v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004); Jones
      v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 417, 586 S.E.2d 111, 113 (2003); Brown
        v. Greenwood Mills, Inc., 366 S.C. 379, 392, 622 S.E.2d 546, 554 (Ct. App.
  2005) cert. denied Jan. 2007; Broughton v. South of the Border,
  336 S.C. 488, 495, 520 S.E.2d 634, 637 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The possibility of
  drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an
  administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe, 336 S.C. at 160, 519 S.E.2d Â at 105; Smith v. NCCI Inc.,
  369 S.C. 236, 247, 631 S.E.2d 268, 274 (Ct. App. 2006); DuRant v. S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Health & Envtl. Control, 361 S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d 704, 707 (Ct.
  App. 2004).
The Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation
  cases and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Isochem,
  365 S.C. at 468, 617 S.E.2d at 376; Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d
  at 495; Muir, 336 S.C. at 281, 519 S.E.2d at 591.Â  The final
  determination of witness credibility and the weight assigned to the evidence is
  reserved to the Appellate Panel.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455,
  535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495.Â  Where
  there are conflicts in the evidence over a factual issue, the findings of the Appellate
  Panel are conclusive.Â  Brown, 366 S.C. at 393, 622 S.E.2d at 554; Etheredge,
  349 S.C. at 455, 562 S.E.2d at 681; see also Mullinax v. Winn Dixie
    Stores, Inc., 318 S.C. 431, 435, 458 S.E.2d 76, 78 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œWhere
  the medical evidence conflicts, the findings of fact of the [Appellate Panel]
  are conclusive.â€).
The
  findings of the Appellate Panel are presumed correct and will be set aside only
  if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Kenco Group, 366 S.C. at 458,
  622 S.E.2d at 581; Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495; Broughton,
  336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 637.Â  The appellate court is prohibited from
  overturning findings of fact of the Appellate Panel unless there is no
  reasonable probability the facts could be as related by the witness upon whose
  testimony the finding was based. Â Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 611 S.E.2d 297, 301, 363 S.C. 612, 621 (Ct. App. 2005) cert. denied July 2007; Hargrove, 360 S.C. at 290, 599 S.E.2d at
  611; Etheredge, 349 S.C. 455-56, 562 S.E.2d at 681.Â  The Appellate
  Panelâ€™s factual findings will normally be upheld; however, such a finding may
  not be based upon surmise, conjecture, or speculation, but must be founded on
  evidence of sufficient substance to afford a reasonable basis for it.Â  Tiller
    v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr. of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 339, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845
  (1999); Muir, 336 S.C. at 282, 519 S.E.2d at 591; Sharpe v. Case
    Produce Co., 329 S.C. 534, 543, 495 S.E.2d 790, 794 (Ct. App. 1997) revâ€™d
      on other grounds.  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Errors of Law
An appellate court may reverse or modify
  the decision of the Appellate Panel if substantial rights of the appellant have
  been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions,
  or decisions are affected by other error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-380(A)(5)(d) (Supp. 2006); Porter v. Labor Depot, Â 372 S.C. 560,
  567, 643 S.E.2d 96, 100 (Ct. App. 2007) cert. denied Dec. 2007; Bass
    v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 467, 617 S.E.2d 369, 376 (Ct. App. 2005) cert
      dismissed as improvidently granted Aug. 2007; Pratt v. Morris Roofing,
        Inc., 353 S.C. 339, 344, 577 S.E.2d 475, 477 (Ct. App. 2003) affâ€™d as
          modified 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 272 (2004).
Section
  14-3-330 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) vests the South Carolina
  Supreme Court with â€œappellate jurisdiction for correction of errors of law in
  law cases . . . .â€Â  Citing both section 14-3-330 and South Carolina Constitution,
  article V, section 5, the Supreme Court has held an appellate court may decide
  novel questions of law with â€œno particular deference to the lower court.â€Â  Madison ex rel. Bryant v. Babcock Ctr., Inc., 371 S.C. 123, 134, 638 S.E.2d
  650, 656 (2006); Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 378, 529 S.E.2d
  528, 533 (2000).Â  Section 14-8-200(a) of the South Carolina Code provides the
  Court of Appeals â€œshall apply the same scope of review that the Supreme Court
  would apply in a similar case.â€Â  (Supp. 2006).  
Pellucidly,
  an appellate courtâ€™s review of factual findings in a workersâ€™ compensation case
  is governed and controlled by the substantial evidence rule.Â  However, an
  appellate court freely and absolutely reviews a trial courtâ€™s decision
  concerning an issue of law.Â  No passivity or complaisance is owed or given to
  the ruling of the Appellate Panel or circuit judge in this context.Â  The highly
  deferential standards statutorily and universally applied in reviewing issues
  of fact, such as the â€œclearly erroneousâ€ and the â€œmanifest errorâ€ standards,
  have no efficacy in regard to an issue of law.Â  The South Carolina Court of
  Appeals exercises freedom and independence in deciding an issue of law in a
  workersâ€™ compensation case. Â Â Â Â Â   
In the
  instant case, the standard of review applied is bifurcated.Â  Whether section
  42-9-60 of the South Carolina Code of Laws (Supp. 2006) bars death benefits to
  the deceased employeeâ€™s mother when the cause of death was suicide is a
  question of law.Â  Hence, we review the Appellate Panelâ€™s ruling to determine if
  it is affected by an error of law. Â See Creech v. Ducane Co., 320
  S.C. 559, 562, 467 S.E.2d 114, 116 (Ct. App. 1995) (recognizing determination
  of whether a claimant sustained an â€œinjury by accidentâ€ within the meaning of
  the workersâ€™ compensation statute is a matter of law).Â  In addition, when the
  evidence gives rise to but one reasonable inference the question becomes one of
  law for the courts to decide.Â  Kinsey v. Champion Am. Serv. Ctr., 268
  S.C. 177, 181, 232 S.E.2d 720, 722 (1977); Sharpe v. Case Produce Co.,329
  S.C. 534, 545, 495 S.E.2d 790, 795 (Ct. App. 1997) revâ€™d on other grounds. 
 
Moreover,
  it is well settled that statutory interpretation is a matter of law. Â Catawba
    Indian Tribe of S.C. v. State, 372 S.C. 519, 524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 754
  (2007); University of Southern California v. Moran, 365 S.C. 270,
  274, 617 S.E.2d 135, 137 (Ct. App. 2005); Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v.
    S.C. Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 621, 611 S.E.2d 297, 301 (Ct. App.
  2005) cert. denied June 2007.Â  Accordingly, we are free to review the
  construction of section 42-9-60 without deference to the Appellate Panel or circuit
  court.Â  Catawba Indian Tribe, 372 S.C. at 524, 642 S.E.2d at 753 (citing Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 327, 534
  S.E.2d 672, 675 (2000)).
The
  substantial evidence rule governs our review of whether Harveyâ€™s suicide was
  (1) the result of spontaneous, impulsive, or instinctive conduct, without
  deliberate or formed intent, or without conscious volition to produce death,
  thus negating his willful intention to kill himself; or (2) a â€œnatural
  consequenceâ€ flowing from his original compensable accident.Â  We may reverse
  the factual findings of the Appellate Panel only if they are unsupported by
  substantial evidence or are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable,
  probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€ Â Liberty Mut. Ins. Co., 363 S.C. at 619, 611 S.E.2d at 300; Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App.
  2004) affâ€™d Â 369 S.C. 176, 631 S.E.2d 899 (2006); S.C. Uninsured
    Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 470, 602 S.E.2d 81, 82 (Ct. App.2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App.
  1996).Â  Concomitantly, if the evidence is undisputed or gives rise to only one
  inference, we may rule as a matter of law.Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist.
    No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 518, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Section
  42-9-60 of the South Carolina Code of Laws
The Workersâ€™ Compensation Act provides
  that â€œ[n]o compensation shall be payable if the injury or death was occasioned
  by the intoxication of the employee or by the wilful intention of the employee
  to injure or kill himself or another.â€[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-60 (Supp. 2006).Â  Cisson contends this provision bars an
  award of death benefits as a matter of law, because Harveyâ€™s suicide was a
  result of his willful intention to kill himself.Â  We agree the strict
  construction of section 42-9-60 bars compensation for death that results from
  â€œthe wilful intentionâ€ of an employee â€œto injure or kill himself.â€Â  Id.
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Principles of Statutory Construction
The issue of interpretation of a statute is a question of law for
  the court.Â  Univ. of S. California v. Moran, 365 S.C. 270, 275, 617
  S.E.2d 135, 137 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Catawba Indian Tribe of South Carolina v.
    State of South Carolina, 327 S.C. 519, 524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 753 (2007) cert.
      denied Oct.Â  1, 2007; Charleston County
        Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers,
  319 S.C. 65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995).
The cardinal rule of statutory
  interpretation is to determine the intent of the legislature. Â Bass v.
    Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 459, 617 S.E.2d 369, 377 (Ct. App. 2005) cert.
      dismissed as improvidently granted Aug. 2007; Georgia-Carolina Bail
        Bonds, Inc. v. County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 22, 579 S.E.2d 334, 336 (Ct. App.
  2003); Smith v. S.C. Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 82, 87, 564 S.E.2d 358, 361 (Ct.
  App. 2002); see also Gordon v. Phillips Utils., Inc., 362 S.C.
  403, 406, 608 S.E.2d 425, 427 (2005) (â€œThe primary purpose in construing a
  statute is to ascertain legislative intent.â€).Â  All rules of statutory
  construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must prevail if
  it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be
  construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute. Â McClanahan
    v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 438, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002); Ray
      Bell Constr. Co. v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville County, 331 S.C. 19, 26, 501
  S.E.2d 725, 729 (1998); State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 365-66, 574
  S.E.2d 203, 206 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Hudson, 336 S.C. 237, 246, 519
  S.E.2d 577, 581 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œOnce the legislature has made [a] choice,
  there is no room for the courts to impose a different judgment based upon their
  own notions of public policy.â€ Â S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mumford,
  299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1989).
The
  legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained primarily from the plain language of
  the statute. Â State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 102, 606 S.E.2d 503, 505
  (Ct. App. 2004); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Stephen
    v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 339, 478 S.E.2d 74, 77 (Ct. App.
  1996).Â  The language must be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject
  matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  Mun. Assâ€™n of S.C. v. AT &
    T Commcâ€™ns of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 580, 606 S.E.2d 468, 470
  (2004); Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178,
  420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Hudson, 336 S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 582. Â 
When a
  statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no room for
  statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to its
  literal meaning. Â Miller v. Aiken, 364 S.C. 303, 307, 613 S.E.2d 364,
  366 (2005); Carolina Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314
  S.C. 137, 139, 442 S.E.2d 177, 179 (1994).Â  If a statuteâ€™s language is
  unambiguous and clear, there is no need to employ the rules of statutory
  construction and this Court has no right to look for or impose another meaning.
  Â Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 373, 585 S.E.2d 292, 298
  (2003); Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 436, 454 S.E.2d
  890, 892 (1995); see also City of Camden v. Brassell, 326 S.C.
  556, 561, 486 S.E.2d 492, 495 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œWhere the language of the
  statute is clear and explicit, the court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters
  into it which are not in the legislatureâ€™s language.â€). Â What a legislature
  says in the text of a statute is considered the best evidence of the legislative
  intent or will. Â Bayle v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 122, 542
  S.E.2d 736, 740 (Ct. App. 2001). Â The words of a statute must be given their
  plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction. Â Durham v. United Cos. Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600, 604, 503 S.E.2d 465, 468
  (1998); Adkins v. Comcar Indus., Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 411, 475 S.E.2d 762,

  from being a burden to others. . . .
	An important function of legislation is to consider and to balance
  the competing interests and equities arising from the conduct of human affairs.Â 
  Workerâ€™s compensation laws are a classic example of this legislative balancing
  of the equities. Â When the legislature has struck a balance by enacting a
  statutory rule, the courts have no prerogative to annul the legislative choice
  by applying â€œchancellorâ€™s footâ€ notions of equity in its place. Â Stated
  differently, it is not the province of this Court to perform legislative
  functions. Â The function of equity is to supplement the law, not to displace
  it.

Id. at 116-17, 580 S.E.2d at 108 (internal
  citations and quotations omitted).Â   
In Petty,
  the North Carolina Supreme Court enunciated a rule that directly contravenes South Carolinaâ€™s judicial policy of strictly construing workersâ€™ compensation statutes.Â  Our
  workersâ€™ compensation law is a creature of statute, enacted in derogation of
  the common law, and we are bound to strictly construe its terms.Â  Brown v.
    Bi-Lo, Inc., 354 S.C. 436, 431, 581 S.E.2d 836, 837 (2003).Â  The language
  in section 42-9-60 bars compensation for death that is the result of a willful
  intention.Â  â€œWillful intentâ€ is the standard to be applied in South Carolina in
  determining whether a self-inflicted injury or death is compensable under
  section 42-9-60.Â  We, therefore, decline to follow the majority of
  jurisdictions, including North Carolina, in embracing the â€œchain of causationâ€
  test.  
III.Â Â Â  Evidentiary Analysis
In
  reversing the Appellate Panelâ€™s award of benefits, the circuit court concluded,
  as a matter of law, that if suicide is compensable at all, it must be the
  result of a spontaneous or uncontrollable impulse or lapse of rationality,
  negating Harveyâ€™s willful intention.Â  Applying the â€œwillful intentâ€ standard, we
  review the record for substantial evidence that Harveyâ€™s death (1) was not the
  result of his willful intention, or (2) was a â€œnatural consequenceâ€ flowing
  from his compensable accident.  
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Negation of Willful Intent 

Under section 42-9-60, suicide is a
  defense to a workersâ€™ compensation death claim, for which the party asserting
  it has the burden of proof.Â  Zeigler v. S. C. Law Enforcement Division,Â 
  250 S.C. 326, 157 S.E.2d 598 (1967); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-80,
  restated in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-60 as amended by Act No. 111, 2007 S.C. Acts
  (â€œIn the event that any person claims that the provisions of this section are
  applicable in any case, the burden of proof shall be upon such person.â€).
â€œ[W]here
  the testimony on the subject produces a conviction in favor of suicide, that
  fact shows that the employer has met the burden resting upon him. Â Only if,
  after a consideration of all of the testimony, a reasonable inference of
  suicide cannot be drawn, can it be said that the employer failed to meet the
  burden.â€Â  In re Crawford, 205 S.C. 72, 72, 30 S.E.2d 841, 847 (1944).
Thompson asserts Cisson failed to prove Harveyâ€™s suicide was the result of his â€œwillful intentionâ€ to kill himself.Â  Concomitantly,
  Thompson contends Harveyâ€™s work injury aggravated his pre-existing psychiatric
  condition to the extent he was no longer in control and his death was not a
  result of willful intention.Â   
Whether
  an employee acted with willful intent to injure or kill himself is a question
  of fact for the Appellate Panel to determine.Â  Youmans v. Coastal Petroleum
    Co., 333 S.C. 195, 199, 508 S.E.2d 43, 45 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The finding
  must be predicated on the employeeâ€™s deliberate or formed intention rather than
  on spontaneous, impulsive, or instinctive conduct.Â  Id.Â  The act must be
  a product of the employeeâ€™s conscious volition.Â  See Zeigler, 250
  S.C. at 331, 157 S.E.2d at 600 (indicating an act of deliberate intent is not
  impulsive or instinctive, but rather it is voluntary conduct, so grave and
  serious as to evidence willful intent).Â   
Approximately
  six months prior to his death Harveyâ€™s deposition was recorded.Â  He was thirty
  years old at the time and claimed to have completed middle school.Â  He never
  obtained his GED and admitted he could read and write very little.Â  Harvey never served in the military or pursued technical training or adult education.Â  He
  lost his driverâ€™s license approximately eleven years prior to his deposition
  due to a DUI charge but had plans to re-apply after the first of the year.Â  Harvey acknowledged one other arrest when he was fourteen for distributing marijuana.Â 
 
Harvey testified he had bipolar disorder for most of his life.Â  He was hospitalized twice
  for suicide attempts following separation from his wife, in the mid 1980s, and
  from his girlfriend, in the mid 1990s.Â  In 1995, Harvey discontinued medication
  for his bipolar disorder.Â  He stated, â€œI was just dealing with it on my own.â€Â 
  He alleged he stopped treatment â€œ[b]ecause I couldnâ€™t afford the medications.â€Â 
  Harvey received no further treatment for his psychiatric condition until
  seeing Dr. Galvarino in 2001.Â  He claimed he had been â€œdealing with it all
  rightâ€ without his medication.Â   
Nine
  months prior to Harveyâ€™s suicide, he began living with his mother after
  separating from his girlfriend.Â  Harvey denied any depression related to the
  break-up of the relationship and professed â€œIâ€™ve been with my mother and everythingâ€™s
  been fine.â€Â  He disavowed any suicide attempts in the last five years, or since
  January of 2000.Â   
At the
  time of his deposition Harveyâ€™s chief complaint was pain resulting from his
  work related injury.Â  He had been treated with physical therapy, medication, steroid
  injections, and a TENS unit.Â  Additionally, he had mobility problems and walked
  with a cane.Â  Harvey alleged his injury caused â€œa lot of depression.â€Â  â€œYou
  know, once you get hurt and you canâ€™t do certain things, you ainâ€™t brining in
  no money, it causes problems.â€
Thompson
  was deposed in June of 2002, three months after Harveyâ€™s death.Â  She identified
  her sonâ€™s psychiatric condition as depression but knew relatively little about his
  medical history.Â  She recalled taking him to a mental health clinic the first
  time he required hospitalization, because â€œhe was real depressed.Â  He had been
  taking drugs.â€Â  However, Thompson was unaware of Harveyâ€™s second
  hospitalization and disclaimed any knowledge he had ever attempted suicide.Â  She
  confirmed he was on quite a few medications when he moved in to live with her,
  but she could only specify Oxycontin as one of them.Â  Thompson said Harvey kept all his medications in his room, and she did not assist him in managing his
  medications, except to transport him to fill his prescriptions.Â  
During
  the nine months Harvey lived with Thompson, she described his mental
  condition:Â  â€œHe had his days.Â  Some days he was better than others, you know,
  but I have seen a lot better.Â  [H]e kindly stayed to hisself.â€Â  When asked if
  he seemed to get better or worse over the course of his nine-month stay,
  Thompson answered:

	I would say that he was about the same, but he couldnâ€™t goâ€”like he
  couldnâ€™t go with me shopping if I actually had to do a lot of shopping because
  he could not walk that far without a cane.Â  Okay?Â  He tried it one time.Â  He
  fell in the store, and I had to get him out of the store.Â  And that got on his
  nerves.Â  Heâ€”I donâ€™t know what all he was having to take for pain, but now,
  [Harvey], heâ€™s not the type of person that would want to take medicine unless
  he really had to.Â  And since this [work] accident, he has been in a lot of
  pain. 

Thompson
  averred Harvey never really discussed his injuries or the details of his
  workersâ€™ compensation claim with her.Â  She simply drove him to his appointments
  with Dr. Shallcross and Dr. Galvarino.Â  She estimated he saw Dr. Galvarino once
  a month and Dr. Shallcross about every three months.Â   
Leading
  up to the day of his death, Thompson did not observe anything different about Harvey, his daily schedule, or a change in his habits.Â  He said nothing to her about any
  particular problems.Â  On the Saturday before he died, she indicated â€œhe didnâ€™t
  act like there was anything at all even bothering him.â€Â   
Thompson
  was unable to awaken Harvey on the morning of March 4, 2002.Â  He had an
  appointment with Dr. Galvarino, and she had planned to get him up early to
  shower.Â  The room was undisturbed; the television was on and Harvey held the
  remote in his hand.Â  Thompson reported he was in his normal sleeping position. Â No
  suicide note was discovered.Â  Thompson professed she believed her sonâ€™s death
  was accidentalâ€”that he ingested his medication, fell asleep, and took it again
  when he later awoke, forgetting about the first dose.Â Â   
In a
  statement clarifying autopsy findings, Dr. Woodard explained:Â   

	Within the gastric contents far in excess of ten intact Oxycontin
  pills of a 10 mg. dose were identified.Â  These were mixed with other
  unidentifiable pill debris.Â  This finding within the gastric contents required
  a willful decision to swallow a massive number of pills.Â  This number of pills
  was far in excess of any individual who mildly exceeded their recommended
  dosage or were elicitly using a controlled substance for recreational
  purposes.Â  

Dr. Shallcrossâ€™s records first mention Harveyâ€™s emotional condition in January of
  2001.Â  On that date, Harvey denied suicidal intent, but admitted he had
  fleeting thoughts of killing himself.Â  Harvey asked for antidepressant
  medication at that time.Â  In May 2001, Dr. Shallcross reported Harvey was not receiving treatment for his pre-existing bipolar disorder, but recommended
  he obtain treatment regardless of his physical status.Â  Dr. Shallcross advised,
  â€œit could reasonably be said that with his problems with job disruption due to
  his work-related injury that being under the care of a psychologist or
  psychiatrist would be more strongly indicated now than in general.â€Â  Dr.
  Shallcross noted he planned to begin tapering off Harveyâ€™s Oxycontin and
  Lortab. Â Â 
On
  August 30, 2001, Dr. Shallcross observed Harveyâ€™s affect was a bit brighter and
  commented that he was seeing Dr. Galvarino for his bipolar disorder.Â  The
  report of his December 6, 2001 visit revealed Harvey was currently using more
  Oxycontin than he was prescribed.Â  Dr. Shallcrossâ€™s impressions of his emotional
  condition were not recorded.Â  Finally, on February 7, 2002, Dr. Shallcross
  wrote: â€œI did not detect any evidence of mania or severe depression in this
  patient and can make no claim as to whether his current status is based on his
  pre-existing bipolar disorder or whether this was aggravated by his work
  condition.â€Â   
Thompson
  relies heavily on the testimony of Harveyâ€™s psychiatrist in support of her
  claim that Harveyâ€™s psychiatric condition negated his willful intention to kill
  himself.Â  Harvey began treating with Dr. Galvarino approximately fifteen months
  after his work injury.Â  Dr. Galvarino characterized Harveyâ€™s emotional state as
  progressively deteriorating. Â He testified in deposition that Harveyâ€™s
  condition seemed to be irreversible, rendering him totally and permanently disabled.Â 
  Dr. Galvarino observed that Harvey was at times â€œoverbearing, losing control
  readily,â€ and at other times â€œin better control . . . speech was coherent and
  relevant and mood was elated.â€Â  In one treatment session Dr. Galvarino noted
  â€œThe new medication is not working.Â  He also has been crying.Â  The patient has
  been target practicing with a pellet gun.Â  He was very angry, about to explode.
  . . .Â  His life is very limited.Â  Heâ€™s about to lose control.â€Â   
Dr. Galvarino opined Harveyâ€™s compensable work injury was causally linked to his
  suicide:

	The patient, as I mentioned earlier, did have a longstanding
  history of depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder and alcohol and drug abuse.Â 
  The patient was involved in an injury in [January][3] of 2000. Â Ever since, the patient has
  been experiencing depression.Â  Seems to me the depression has worsened.Â  When I
  saw him the patient was evaluated, given treatment. . . .Â  Treatment has
  failed.Â  The patientâ€™s illness has progressed to an extent that he could no
  longer bear it; henceforth, his suicide.Â  Itâ€™s my opinion that patientâ€™s
  depression was significantly exacerbated by his injury.Â  The patientâ€™s suicide
  was secondary to his depression, was exacerbated to a point that the patient
  could no longer handle it. . . . 

Although
  Dr. Galvarinoâ€™s testimony may support a chain of causation between Harveyâ€™s work injury and his suicide, chain of causation is not the test for
  compensability of a self-inflicted injury under our statute and judicial
  precedent.Â  If Harveyâ€™s death is to be compensable at all, it must be the
  result of a spontaneous or uncontrollable impulse, or lapse of conscious
  volition negating his willful intention.Â  The record before us contains little evidence
  to support that Harveyâ€™s suicide meets that standard.
Substantial
  evidence unquestionably documents Harveyâ€™s injury, pain, and severe psychiatric
  symptoms.Â  However, evidence in the record tending to negate willful intention
  is de minimus.Â  Dr. Galvarinoâ€™s medical reports Â indicate Harvey was at times feeling â€œout of controlâ€ and unable to cope.Â  Yet, at other times Harvey appeared to be managing his illness without extreme distress.Â  Testimony from his
  mother and notes from Dr. Shallcross reveal nothing to indicate Harvey was not rational or in control of his own volition in the months prior to his death.Â 
 
Harveyâ€™s own deposition testimony appears to reflect a fairly intact thought process.Â  He
  was able to recount his medical history and the past events leading up to his
  previous hospitalizations.Â  He acknowledged his suicide attempts resulted from
  depression over failed relationships.Â  Moreover, Harvey apparently understood
  the efficacy of medication for his psychiatric symptoms and asked Dr. Shallcross to prescribe an antidepressant when his emotional condition
  warranted it.Â   
Harveyâ€™s two previous suicide attempts inherently suggest deliberative thinking that
  contemplates oneâ€™s own demise as a way of coping with depression.Â  Dr. Shallcross mentioned Harvey had fleeting thoughts of killing himself, and Dr.
  Galvarinoâ€™s records reflect concern about Harveyâ€™s feelings of helplessness,
  hopelessness, and suicidal ideation.Â  Harveyâ€™s admission that he had been
  target practicing with a pellet gun raises additional concern about his coping
  strategy.Â  Â Â 
Neither
  Dr. Shallcross nor Dr. Galvarino opined Harveyâ€™s suicide was the result of a mental
  process that negated his willful intention.Â  Though Dr. Galvarino reported
  episodes of severe distress, in the end he asserted that, if Harvey committed
  suicide, it was intentional, because by definition, suicide is intentional.Â 
  Finally, Dr. Woodard concluded, to a reasonable degree of medical certainty,
  that Harveyâ€™s death was the result of a willful massive overdose of
  medication.Â   
Â Considering
  all of the direct and circumstantial evidence, including lay and expert
  testimony, to conclude Harveyâ€™s suicide was not the result of his willful
  intention would be surmise, conjecture, or speculation.Â  The record fails to
  support that Harvey was overcome by a spontaneous, impulsive, or instinctive
  urge, or that he was devoid of deliberate or formed intention.Â   
The
  chain of causation Dr. Galvarino posited may have established that the
  aggravation of Harveyâ€™s psychiatric condition was compensable.Â  Nevertheless,
  willful intention was the independent intervening variable that severed the causal
  relationship between the injury and suicide.Â  Without evidence negating willful
  intention, the only reasonable inference is that Harveyâ€™s suicide was the
  result of his willful intention.Â   
The
  Appellate Panel erred as a matter of law in apparently evaluating
  compensability for Harveyâ€™s suicide using the chain of causation test.Â  The
  appropriate standard in this state is willful intent.Â  Moreover, the decision
  that Harveyâ€™s suicide was compensable is clearly erroneous in view of substantial
  evidence in the record that Harveyâ€™s death was the result of his willful
  intention.  
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Natural Consequence of Compensable
  Injury
Thompson maintains Harveyâ€™s suicide is
  compensable because it was a â€œnatural consequenceâ€ of his work-related injury.Â 
  We disagree.  
 â€œA
  [mental] condition which is induced by a compensable physical injury is . . .
  causally related to that injury.â€Â  Getsinger v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas
    Corp., 335 S.C. 77, 81, 515 S.E.2d 104, 106 (Ct. App. 1999) (quoting Estridge
      v. Joslyn Clark Controls, Inc., 325 S.C. 532, 538-39, 482 S.E.2d 577,
  580-81 (Ct. App. 1997)).Â   
A
  work-related accident which aggravates or accelerates a pre-existing condition,
  infirmity, or disease is compensable. Â Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360
  S.C. 276, 599 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Brown v. R.L. Jordan Oil
    Co., 291 S.C. 272, 353 S.E.2d 280 (1987); Sturkie v. Ballenger Corp.,
  268 S.C. 536, 235 S.E.2d 120 (1977); Mullinax v. Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc.,
  318 S.C. 431, 458 S.E.2d 76 (Ct. App. 1995)). Â 
Aggravation
  of pre-existing psychiatric problems is compensable if that aggravation is
  caused by a work-related physical injury. Â Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 493, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001); Smith v. NCCI, Inc.,
  369 S.C. 236, 254, 631 S.E.2d 268, 278 (Ct. App. 2006).
A
  condition is compensable unless it is due solely to the natural progression of
  a pre-existing condition.Â  Mullinax, 318 S.C. at 437, 458 S.E.2d at 80. Â It
  is no defense that the accident, standing alone, would not have caused the
  claimantâ€™s condition, because the employer takes the employee as it finds him
  or her.Â  Id. â€œ[A]ggravation of a pre-existing condition is compensable
  where disability is continued for a longer time, even though no disability
  would normally have resulted from the injury alone, or even if the aggravation
  would have caused no injury to an employee who was not afflicted with the
  condition.â€ Â Id. (internal quotations omitted).
The â€œnatural
  consequencesâ€ flowing from a compensable injury, absent an independent
  intervening cause, are compensable.Â  Id. at 436, 458 S.E.2d at 79.Â  â€œThe
  causal sequence . . . may be more indirect or complex, but as long as the
  causal connection is in fact present the compensability of the subsequent
  condition is beyond question.â€Â  Id. at 437, 458 S.E.2d at 80 (quoting Arthur
  Larson, The Law of Workmenâ€™s Compensation Â§ 13.11(b) (1994)).  
In Mullinax,
  the claimant sustained a work-related injury to her back and sought medical
  treatment.Â  Subsequently, she developed incontinence she claimed resulted from
  the injury or from the exercise treatment prescribed for the injury.Â  318 S.C.
  at 433, 458 S.E.2d at 78.Â  The employer contended claimantâ€™s incontinence was
  caused by a prior hysterectomy and â€œnot work related nor related to any problem
  caused by treatment for her work-related injury.â€Â  Id. at 434, 458
  S.E.2d at 78.Â  The single commissioner, whose findings were adopted by the
  Appellate Panel, found no causal relationship between the claimantâ€™s
  incontinence and her work-related injury.Â  Reviewing the record for substantial
  evidence supporting the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision, the court of appeals
  determined â€œall of the evidence shows that, the accident or the exercises, a
  natural consequence of the accident, at a minimum aggravated the incontinence.â€Â 
  The court reasoned:Â   

	The Commission committed legal error when it based its decision
  solely on the lack of a medical opinion stating [claimantâ€™s] injury caused the
  incontinence. Â In doing so, it ignored the medical and circumstantial evidence
  in the record, which shows either the injury or the treatment for the injury
  aggravated the incontinence.Â  This is true even though [the claimant] may have
  suffered some degree of incontinence before the injury, and even though her
  prior medical history made her condition more susceptible to aggravation by the
  injury or its treatment. Â Both circumstantial evidence and lay testimony are
  competent in workerâ€™s compensation cases if the injury and disability can be
  reasonably connected through their use.

Following
  the reasoning in Mullinax, the argument could be made in the case sub judice that Harveyâ€™s knee injury caused the chronic pain, a natural
  consequence of the injury, which aggravated his pre-existing psychiatric
  condition.Â  However, Thompson extends the causal relationship even further,
  claiming as a natural consequence of Harveyâ€™s aggravated pre-existing
  psychiatric condition, he committed suicide two years later.Â   
As we
  held in Mullinax, natural consequences flowing from a compensable injury
  are only compensable absent an independent intervening cause. Â 318 S.C. at 436,
  458 S.E.2d at 79.Â  Yet, suicide, by definition, is an act of willful intention.
  Â Suicide is an unnatural consequence of work related depression because it
  injects the willful intention of the employee into the calculation.Â  The
  employeeâ€™s willful intention to kill himself is the independent intervening
  cause that severs the link with the compensable injury.Â   
Moreover,
  while suicide resulting from depression is foreseeable, it is not a natural
  consequence of depression.Â  Conceptually, the notion of natural consequence connotes
  the inevitability of a result beyond the employeeâ€™s control.Â   
CONCLUSION
We rule,
  as a matter of law, that the plain language of section 42-9-60 bars
  compensation for Harveyâ€™s death resulting from his â€œwilful intention to kill
  himself.â€Â  The test in South Carolina for evaluating compensability is whether
  the employeeâ€™s suicide was the result of â€œwillful intent.â€Â  Unless substantial
  evidence supports a finding that â€œwillful intentâ€ is negated by spontaneous,
  impulsive, or instinctive conduct, without deliberate or formed intention, or
  without conscious volition to produce death, the statutory bar to workersâ€™
  compensation benefits applies.Â   
After
  thorough review of the record, we conclude the evidence fails to establish that
  Harveyâ€™s psychiatric condition negated his willful intent to kill himself.Â 
  Willful intention, as an independent intervening variable, broke the chain of
  causation between the work-related injury and suicide.Â  Consequently, Harveyâ€™s suicide was not causally related to or a â€œnatural consequenceâ€ flowing from his
  work-related injury.  
Accordingly,
  the order of the circuit court is  
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS,
  J. and GOOLSBY, AJ., concur.

[1] Â The South Carolina General Assembly
  amended section 42-9-60 on June 25, 2007, by adding the following language to
  the existing text: â€œIn the
  event that any person claims that the provisions of this section are applicable
  in any case, the burden of proof shall be upon such person.â€Â  This amendment
  and other legislative changes in the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act apply only to
  injuries occurring on or after the effective date of the 2007 enactment, July
  1, 2007.Â  Act No. 111, 2007 S.C. Acts.Â   
[2] Amendments by Act No. 111, 2007 S.C.
  Acts to this section apply to injuries that occur on or after the effective
  date of July 1, 2007.
[3]Â  Dr. Galvarino confirmed an error in his notes
  indicating the work injury occurred in June rather than in January was
  typographical.Â
