title: Simpson v. Simpson
description: The Court of Appeals affirmed the family court's order denying the husband's request for the family court's recusal.  The husband argued the family court was incorrect to not recuse itself after making its own sua sponte motion for recusal.  The Court of Appeals disagreed, finding the family court's oral motion was not binding and the husband failed to present any evidence of prejudice or bias on the family court's behalf which would require recusal, thus making the family court's refusal to recuse itself proper.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				William R.
      Simpson, Jr., Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Becky H. Simpson
      and Wade Ingle, Defendants, of whom Becky H. Simpson is Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Clarendon County
Â FrancesÂ  P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4340
Heard November 6, 2007 â€“ Filed February 8,
  2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Steven S. McKenzie, of Manning, for Appellant.
				James McLaren, C. Dixon Lee, and Jan L. Warner, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  William Robert Simpson, Jr., (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s denial of
  Husbandâ€™s motion for the family courtâ€™s recusal based on its finding that there
  are no conflicts of interests or other reasons why it should disqualify itself
  or grant a new trial.Â  We affirm.Â  Â 
FACTS
Husband
  is the son of Daisy Wallace Simpson (Mother) and William Robert Simpson, Sr.
  (Father). Â In December 2004, Judge R. Wright Turbeville granted Mother and
  Father a divorce.Â  As a shareholder/member of W.R. Simpson Farms, L.L.C.,
  Husband was named a party to Mother and Fatherâ€™s divorce action. Â 
Husband and Becky H. Simpson (Wife) were granted a divorce in
  March 2005 through a bifurcated Decree of Divorce. Â In March 2006, Judge
  Frances P. Segars-Andrews heard the remaining issues pursuant to the bifurcated
  Divorce Decree.Â  Husband and Wife entered into a Consent Order on the issues of
  child custody and visitation, and Judge Segars-Andrews issued written
  instructions for a Final Order on all remaining issues.  
Lon Shull (Shull), a partner in the law firm of Andrews and Shull
  in Mt. Pleasant, South Carolina, was a witness, via affidavit, at the request
  of Motherâ€™s attorneys, in Mother and Fatherâ€™s divorce action regarding the
  issue of attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Shullâ€™s law partner is Mark O. Andrews, the husband
  of Judge Segars-Andrews. Â Â 
Subsequent to Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ issuance of instructions for
  the Final Order, Husband filed a motion for a new trial which asserted a conflict
  of interest had not been disclosed. Â Husband alleged a conflict due to Shullâ€™s
  involvement in Mother and Fatherâ€™s case and his connection to Judge
  Segars-Andrewsâ€™ husband.Â  Husbandâ€™s motion did not allege any prejudice or bias
  as a result of this conflict, and after a hearing on this motion, Judge
  Segars-Andrews denied the motion.Â Â Â   
At this same hearing, however, Judge Segars-Andrews, acting sua
  sponte, orally stated she would recuse herself.Â  Judge Segars-Andrews raised
  the question of whether she should disqualify herself because James McLaren,
  Wifeâ€™s counsel in the present divorce action, and Shull had been co-counsel in
  a personal injury case.Â  This unrelated case ended in late 2004 or early 2005
  and resulted in a substantial fee to Shullâ€™s firm, which in turn benefited his
  law partner, Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ husband.Â  Â Â Â 
After receiving memos from both parties on this question, Judge
  Segars-Andrews found the situation did not require her to disqualify herself,
  and therefore, she had a duty to hear the case.Â  This appeal follows.Â  Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œUnder South Carolina law, if there is no evidence of judicial
  prejudice, a judgeâ€™s failure to disqualify [herself] will not be reversed on
  appeal.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 524, 599 S.E.2d 114, 118 (2004).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
We begin by addressing Wifeâ€™s argument, which was made for the
  first time at oral argument, that this Court is procedurally barred from
  hearing this appeal.Â  Wife argues a denial of a motion for disqualification of
  a judge is an interlocutory order, and therefore, it may only be reviewed by
  this Court on an appeal from a final order.Â  See Rogers v. Wilkins,
  275 S.C. 28, 29-30, 267 S.E.2d 86, 87 (1980) (finding the denial of a motion
  for disqualification is interlocutory and reviewable only after an appeal from
  final judgment); see Townsend v. Townsend, 323 S.C. 309, 312, 474
  S.E.2d 424, 427 (1996) (â€œA denial of a motion for disqualification of a judge
  is an interlocutory order not affecting the merits and, thus, is reviewable
  only on appeal from a final order.â€). Â 
Wife is correct in her statement of the law; however, the case
  before us is distinguishable from the cases Wife references to support her
  argument.Â  In the current case, although two separate appeals[1] have been filed, each follows a final
  order from the family court.Â  Neither party moved to consolidate the two
  appeals, so they have proceeded separately.Â  Because this appeal of Judge
  Segars-Andrewsâ€™ denial of a motion for disqualification follows a final order,
  it is not an interlocutory appeal and is, therefore, properly before this
  Court.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
Husband argues the family court erred in overturning its sua sponte recusal.Â  We disagree. Â Â Â  Â 
South Carolinaâ€™s Code of Judicial Conduct states, â€œA judge shall avoid impropriety and the
  appearance of impropriety in all of the judgeâ€™s activities.â€ Â Canon 2 of the
  Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR.Â  The Code requires a judge to
  â€œdisqualify himself or herself in a proceeding in which the judgeâ€™s
  impartiality might reasonably be questioned . . . .â€Â  Canon 2 of the Code of
  Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR.Â  When disqualification is not required,
  however, the Code states, â€œA judge shall hear and decide matters assigned to
  the judge . . . .â€Â  Canon 3B(1) of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501,
  SCACR.Â  â€œA judgeâ€™s impartiality might reasonably be questioned when his [or
  her] factual findings are not supported by the record.â€Â  Patel, 359 S.C.
  at 524, 599 S.E.2d at 118.Â   
In the current case, Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ findings are supported
  by the record.Â  Judge Segars-Andrews provided a detailed list of findings in
  support of her decision on how to equitably divide the assets of Husband and
  Wife.Â  Judge Segars-Andrews made these findings and included them in her
  â€œInstructions for Orderâ€ before she remembered the previous relationship
  between her husbandâ€™s law partner and Wifeâ€™s counsel. Â Facts in the record support
  Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ findings. Â We see no evidence showing bias or prejudice.Â 
 
The party seeking disqualification must do more than merely allege
  bias on the judgeâ€™s behalf; the party must present some evidence of judicial
  prejudice or bias.Â  Id. at 524, 599 S.E.2d at 118.Â  â€œIn applying Canon
  3[(E)](1), the South Carolina Supreme Court has stated that the movant or
  petitioner must show some evidence of the bias or prejudice of the judge.â€Â  Lyvers
    v. Lyvers, 280 S.C. 361, 367, 312 S.E.2d 590, 594 (Ct. App. 1984) (internal
  quotations and citations omitted).Â  When an appellant offers no evidence to
  support his claim of partiality, the trial judge is correct to deny a Motion
  for Recusal.Â  See Christensen v. Mikell, 324 S.C. 70, 74, 476
  S.E.2d 692, 694 (1996) (â€œAppellant offered no evidence to support his claim of
  partiality.Â  Accordingly, the trial judge properly denied the Motion to
  Recuse.â€).  
Husband has not shown any evidence of bias or prejudice on behalf
  of Judge Segars-Andrews.Â  Husband argues Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ own statements
  about the need to disclose the previous working relationship between her
  husbandâ€™s law partner and Wifeâ€™s counsel might reasonably question her
  impartiality.Â  Husband fails, however, to provide any evidence of how the
  former relationship actually resulted in some prejudice or bias in Judge
  Segars-Andrewsâ€™ ruling.Â  Thus, Judge Segars-Andrews was correct to deny
  Husbandâ€™s request for recusal.Â  Â Â 
In Doe v. Howe, the trial judge chose to make disclosures to
  both sides about his contacts with Howe and his law clerkâ€™s contacts with the
  law firm representing Howe. Â 367 S.C. 432, 439, 626 S.E.2d 25, 28 (Ct. App.
  2005).Â  The trial judge did not then recuse himself; Doe, therefore, alleged
  judicial prejudice.Â  Id.Â  This Court held,  

	Because Doe made no showing here of actual prejudice, we find no
  abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to disqualify himself.Â  If anything,
  the trial judge demonstrated sensitivity toward any concerns Doe might have had
  regarding his impartiality by voluntarily making full disclosure of his and his
  law clerkâ€™s contacts with Howe and Howeâ€™s counsel.Â  

Id. at 441, 626 S.E.2d at 29.Â  Â Â Â Â 
Just as in Doe, we find Husband has made no showing of
  actual prejudice on behalf of Judge Segars-Andrews.Â  We find Judge
  Segars-Andrewsâ€™ remarks about her concern for not disclosing the information at
  the beginning of the hearing do not show any bias or prejudice but instead show
  her sensitivity to any apprehension each side might have in her ability to make
  a fair and impartial ruling in the case.Â   
Husband also argues Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ written order denying
  his request for recusal is a reversal of her earlier oral disqualification, but
  we find this argument without merit.Â  Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ oral ruling
  regarding recusal did not constitute a final order by the Judge, and therefore,
  her final order denying Husbandâ€™s request for recusal was not a reversal of a
  previous order.Â  South Carolina law is clear that â€œ[n]o order is final until it
  is written and entered.â€ Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 620, 571
  S.E.2d 92, 96 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œUntil written and entered, the trial judge
  retains discretion to change his [or her] mind and amend his [or her] oral
  ruling accordingly.â€Â  Id. at 621, 571 S.E.2d at 96.Â  A written order may
  be issued which is inconsistent with a prior oral ruling, and to the extent the
  two conflict, the written order controls.Â  Id. at 621, 571 S.E.2d at
  97.Â  â€œThe written order . . . constitutes the final judgment of the court.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
Judge Segars-Andrews made an initial oral ruling deciding she
  would recuse herself from this matter but also agreed to accept memoranda on
  the issue.Â  After reviewing the memoranda and affidavits from each side,
  however, she found she had no reason to recuse herself and, therefore, had a
  duty to adjudicate the case.Â  Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ final, written order denied
  Husbandâ€™s request for recusal.Â  The written order controls.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Having
  found no evidence that could question the impartiality of Judge Segars-Andrews,
  or any other reason requiring her recusal, we find Canon 3B(1) to be
  controlling, which imposes a â€œduty to sit.â€Â  When disqualification is not
  required, the South Carolina Code of Judicial Conduct holds, â€œA judge shall hear and decide matters assigned to the judge . . . .â€Â  Canon 3B(1) of the Code
  of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR (emphasis added).Â  This duty has been recognized
  and imposed in both state and federal courts.Â  See McBeth v. Nissan
    Motor Corp. U.S.A., 921 F.Supp. 1473, 1477 (D.S.C. 1996) (â€œNo judge, of
  course, has a duty to sit where his impartiality might be reasonably
  questioned.â€); Barritt v. State, No. CACR06-1261, 2007 WL 2713593, at *6
  (Ark. Ct. App. Sept. 19, 2007) (â€œWhen recusal is in issue, this court has held
  that a judge has a duty to sit on a case unless there is a valid reason to
  disqualify . . . .â€) (internal citations omitted); In re Turney, 533
  A.2d 916, 920 (Md. 1987) (â€œMoreover, a judgeâ€™s duty to sit where not
  disqualified is equally as strong as the duty not to sit where disqualified.â€); Adair v. State, 709 N.W.2d 567, 579 (Mich. 2006) (â€œ[W]here the standards
  governing disqualification have not been met, disqualification is not optional;
  rather, it is prohibited.â€)(internal quotations and citations omitted); Â Millen
    v. Eighth Judicial Dist. ex rel. County of Clark, 148 P.3d 694, 700
  (Nev. 2006) (â€œThus, a judge has a general duty to sit, unless a judicial canon,
  statute, or rule requires the judgeâ€™s disqualification.â€); Tennant v. Marion
    Health Care Found., Inc., 459 S.E.2d 374, 385 (W. Va. 1995) (â€œAlso
  important, however, is the rule that a judge has an equally strong duty to sit
  where there is no valid reason for recusal.â€).  
CONCLUSION
Husband has failed to present any evidence of prejudice or bias on
  Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ behalf which would require her to recuse herself, and
  thus, Judge Segars-Andrews had the duty to sit for this matter. Â Â 
Accordingly, the
  family courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.  

[1] This appeal concerns Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ denial of Husbandâ€™s motion for
  disqualification.Â  Husband also appeals Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ Final Order for
  Equitable Division, Child Support, Attorneyâ€™s Fees and Costs.

title: Simpson v. Simpson
description: In this domestic action, the husband appealed on several grounds, including several aspects of the family courtâ€™s equitable distribution award, the inclusion of the husbandâ€™s business in the award, the valuation of certain marital property, and the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to the wife.  The Court of Appeals affirmed, finding the family court considered both partiesâ€™ direct and indirect contributions in its 60/40 split of the marital estate in favor of the husband.  The Court also found the husbandâ€™s fifty percent share in the business was not a gift from his father, rather it was payment for labor expended during the marriage.  While the land on which the marital home existed was a gift from the husbandâ€™s father, the house was built using the partiesâ€™ marital funds, such that it was not error to conclude the land had been transmuted into marital property.  Last, the Court determined it was not an abuse to award attorneyâ€™s fees to the wife when she secured favorable results, the husband had greater means to pay the fees, and his lack of candor and cooperation prolonged litigation and increased both partiesâ€™ fees.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				William R.
      Simpson, Jr., Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Becky H.
      Simpson and  
        		Wade Ingle, Defendants,
          of whom Becky H. Simpson is Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Clarendon County
Â Frances P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4341
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  February 8, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Steven S. McKenzie, of Manning, for Appellant.
				James McLaren, C. Dixon Lee, Jan L. Warner, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this domestic action, William Robert Simpson, Jr., (Husband) appeals the family
  courtâ€™s order, arguing the family court erred in (1) its equitable
  distribution of marital property; (2) finding Simpson Farms, LLC, was marital
  property; (3) failing to correctly ascertain the inventory of the Buck and Bull
  store; (4) failing to give Husband credit for $16,000 in monies he paid to his
  former wife, Becky H. Simpson (Wife); (5) finding the partiesâ€™ residence was transmuted
  into marital property; and (6) awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We
  affirm.
FACTS
Husband
  and Wife were married on September 3, 1989.Â  At the time of the marriage,
  Husband was nineteen and Wife was seventeen years of age.Â  During the marriage,
  Wife primarily stayed at home and took care of the partiesâ€™ two children.Â  She
  maintained periodic outside employment, including a job at the childrenâ€™s
  private school, Clarendon Hall, for which the parties received reduced
  tuition.Â   
Throughout
  the marriage, Husband worked as a farmer with his father, William Simpson, Sr.
  (Simpson, Sr.).[1]Â 
  In exchange for Husband earning a nominal salary and working hard, Simpson, Sr.
  awarded him a fifty percent interest in Simpson Farms.Â  Husband also bought other
  property that he farmed separately from his father.Â  He financed the purchase
  of the additional land in various ways.Â  At times, he farmed the land or cut
  timber in order to pay the purchase price.Â  At other times, he borrowed money
  from banks.Â  Â 
At the beginning of the marriage, the parties purchased a mobile
  home, using $6,000 Wife inherited, which was located on Simpson, Sr.â€™s
  property.Â  Over time, the parties cleared the land, and in 1995, they built the
  marital residence.Â  On May 15, 1996, Simpson, Sr. formally deeded the property to
  Husband.Â  At the time of the final hearing, the residence had $78,600
  outstanding on the mortgage.Â   
In late 2003, Wife began acting somewhat erratically and appeared
  depressed.Â  Husband found Wife to be more irritable and believed she preferred
  to be alone without him or the children.Â  To support Husbandâ€™s claim that Wife
  was acting irrationally, he testified that when Wife returned from a trip to Florida in July 2004, she had three tattoos.Â  Eventually, Wife was diagnosed as bipolar.Â  Thereafter,
  Husband asked Wife for a divorce.Â   
At this point, Wife was not represented by counsel.Â  Husband took
  Wife, who was accompanied by her elderly grandfather, to his attorneyâ€™s office
  to sign a separation agreement.Â  Wife signed the separation agreement, which
  was later approved by the family court.Â  When she signed the agreement, Wife claimed
  she was unaware of the partiesâ€™ finances because Husband handled the financial
  aspects of their marriage.Â  In the time frame between Husband asking Wife for a
  divorce and the signing of the separation agreement, Wife began dating Wade
  Ingle. Â 
A few months later, Wife retained counsel and moved to have the separation
  agreement set aside, claiming she was undergoing psychotherapy and taking
  medication at the time she signed the separation agreement.Â  She also argued
  Husband had not made a full financial disclosure.Â  The family court, noting it
  would not have approved the separation agreement had it known Wifeâ€™s mental
  condition, set aside the agreement.Â   
After the family court set aside the separation agreement, Husband
  instituted this action seeking a divorce based upon Wifeâ€™s adultery.Â  While the
  divorce proceedings were pending, Husband closed the Buck and Bull store he
  operated and attempted to auction off the inventory.Â  The family court halted
  the sale in order to determine the inventoryâ€™s value.Â   
The family court subsequently issued a bifurcated decree of
  divorce, granting Husband a divorce based upon Wifeâ€™s adultery, which occurred
  after the parties separated.Â  The family court left open all other issues,
  noting, â€œThis [o]rder shall not be construed as making any finding relative to
  the issues of fault of either party . . . as may affect equitable division,
  custody, counsel fees, [and] suit money.â€Â  Â 
After a two-day hearing on the remaining issues, the family court
  issued its final order.[2]Â 
  The order provided Wife was barred from alimony because of her adultery.Â  The
  family court awarded Husband sixty percent of the marital property, totaling
  $320,655, and awarded Wife forty percent of the marital estate, totaling
  $213,876, pursuant to the family courtâ€™s consideration of the equitable
  distribution statute.Â  Additionally, the family court ordered Husband to pay
  half of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â   
Accordingly, Husband filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to
  reconsider, which the family court denied.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On
  appeal from the family court, this Court has the authority to find facts in
  accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â 
  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s
  findings, and we remain mindful that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses,
  is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to
  their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d
  541, 541 (1981).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Equitable Distribution
Husband argues
  the family court erred in its equitable distribution of the marital property.Â 
  Specifically, Husband contends the family courtâ€™s equitable division attempted
  to compensate Wife for her failure to receive alimony.Â  We disagree.
The
  division of marital property is within the sound discretion of the family
  court, and on appeal, it will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Greene
    v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 340, 569 S.E.2d 393, 399 (Ct. App. 2002).Â 
  Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) imparts the family court
  with fifteen factors to consider in equitably apportioning marital property.Â  The
  statute vests the family court with the discretion to decide the weight to
  assign various factors.Â  See id. (â€œIn making apportionment, the
  court must give weight in such proportion as it finds appropriate . . . .â€).Â  On
  appeal, â€œthis [C]ourt looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment, and
  it is irrelevant that this [C]ourt might have weighed specific factors
  differently than the family court.â€Â  Doe v. Doe, 370 S.C. 206, 213-14,
  634 S.E.2d 51, 55 (Ct. App. 2006).Â   
In Berry v. Berry, 294 S.C. 334, 335, 364 S.E.2d 463, 464 (1988), the family
  courtâ€™s order, which awarded an adulterous spouse an equal share of the marital
  property, provided,  

	Although
  it was . . . adultery that precipitated this divorce action, no deduction has
  been made from her share by reason of her fault. . . . Were it not for the
  length of this marriage and the fact that [she] is barred from alimony, I would
  have awarded her a substantially lower percentage of the marital property.

In affirming this Courtâ€™s
  reversal of the family courtâ€™s order, the Supreme Court noted, â€œ[T]he
  preclusion of an alimony award to a spouse cannot be used to increase an
  equitable distribution award.â€Â  Id.Â  
In the present
  case, Husband alleges the family court attempted to compensate Wife through
  equitable distribution because she was statutorily barred from receiving
  alimony.Â  He points to what he believes is the family courtâ€™s â€œskewedâ€ factual
  findings in favor of Wife to award her forty percent of the marital estate.
We find the record
  fails to support Husbandâ€™s contention.Â  In its order, the family court granted
  Husband a divorce based upon Wifeâ€™s adultery that took place after the parties
  separated.Â  Further, the order provided, â€œThere is no evidence of marital
  misconduct from either party that would rise to the level to [a]ffect the
  division of property.Â  The wifeâ€™s adultery took place only after the partiesâ€™
  separation.â€Â  Unlike the situation presented in Berry, the family court
  specifically stated Wifeâ€™s marital misconduct did not affect the equitable
  distribution.Â   
In
  this case, the family court awarded Husband twenty percent more than Wife,
  dividing the property in a sixty-forty split. Â The court took into
  consideration the direct and indirect contributions of both parties and the
  substantial â€œsweat equityâ€ of Husband. Â The award considered the appropriate
  statutory factors and this Stateâ€™s public policy that a partyâ€™s marital
  misconduct does not justify a severe penalty for equitable apportionment
  purposes.Â  See Doe, 370 S.C. at 216, 634 S.E.2d at 57 (finding South Carolina law â€œexpressly disallow[s] fault as a penaltyâ€ in determining equitable
  apportionment between a husband and wife).Â  Therefore, we agree with the family
  court that a forty percent award of the marital property to Wife is proper.

    II.Â Â Marital Property
Husband argues the
  family court erred in finding Simpson Farms was marital property.Â  Husband
  maintains his fifty percent interest in Simpson Farms was a gift from Simpson,
  Sr. and, as such, is a nonmarital asset.Â  We disagree.
Â Marital property is defined as â€œall real and personal
  property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which
  is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation . . . regardless
  of how legal title is held.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2006). Â However,
  property may be considered nonmarital if it is acquired by gift or
  inheritance.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(1).Â  Because of the general presumption
  that property acquired during the marriage is an asset of the marriage, â€œ[t]he
  burden to show an exemption under S.C. Code Ann. Section 20-7-473 is
  upon the one claiming that property acquired during the marriage is not
  marital.â€Â  Brandi v. Brandi, 302 S.C. 353, 356, 396 S.E.2d 124, 126 (Ct.
  App. 1990) (citations omitted).
Husband
  points to the testimony of Wifeâ€™s expert, Mark Hobbs, a certified public
  accountant, to show Simpson Farms was a gift from his father.Â  During Simpson,
  Sr.â€™s divorce proceedings, Hobbs testified the only way Husband could have
  amassed all of his property was through gift or inheritance because the income
  shown on Husbandâ€™s tax returns could not support Husbandâ€™s vast land holdings.Â 
  During this trial, Hobbs testified he still believed his earlier conclusions to
  be true.Â  Â Â 
After
  reviewing the record, we find Husband mischaracterizes and omits much of Hobbsâ€™ testimony.Â  Although Hobbs stated he believed Husbandâ€™s interest in Simpson Farms
  was a gift, he did so to highlight his belief that Husband could not have
  amassed his land holdings with the little amount of income he reported on his
  tax returns.Â  In fact, the very substance of Hobbsâ€™ testimony indicated
  Husbandâ€™s financial records were inaccurate and incomplete.Â  Hobbs noted
  Husbandâ€™s personal expenses â€œgreatly exceededâ€ the amount of money he reported
  as income.Â  Further, Hobbs testified he did not see any gift tax returns filed
  by Husband or Simpson, Sr. to verify Simpson Farms was a gift rather than
  something Husband acquired through his hard work during the marriage.Â  In
  addition, the agreement between Husband and Simpson, Sr. provides, â€œ[A]ll farm
  equipment and farm land of Simpson Farms will become shared equally for
  invested interest for work on [the] farm . . . .â€Â  Husbandâ€™s own testimony at
  the hearing was that he worked for his interest in Simpson Farms: â€œI earned it
  all, I worked for it, and he gave it to me.â€ Â 
The
  evidence in this case establishes Simpson Farms was marital property, and Husband
  has failed to carry his burden to show otherwise.Â  During the marriage, Husband
  farmed and received a nominal salary of $120 a week in exchange for an interest
  in Simpson Farms.Â  Husbandâ€™s fifty percent interest in Simpson Farms was
  payment for labor expended during the marriage, and therefore, the family court
  properly concluded it was an asset of the marriage.
III.Â Â Inventory of Buck
  and Bull  
Husband avers the
  family court failed to properly determine what the inventory of the Buck and
  Bull store included at the time this action was commenced. Â We disagree.
Although the sale
  of the storeâ€™s inventory was halted pursuant to a court order, Husband offered
  no figure during the hearing as to the inventoryâ€™s value at the time he
  instituted this action. Â Therefore, we cannot determine how much this value
  depleted between the filing of the action and the final hearing. Â See Honea
    v. Honea,  292 S.C. 456, 458, 357 S.E.2d 191, 192 (Ct. App. 1987)
  (â€œWe have stated before, and we reiterate here, that a party cannot sit back at
  trial without offering proof, then come to this Court complaining of the
  insufficiency of the evidence to support the family courtâ€™s findings.â€).Â  Further,
  even if the family courtâ€™s valuation was too low, as Husband alleges, because
  the family court awarded him the inventory, we can discern no prejudice to
  Husband if the inventory should be worth more than what the family court
  found.Â  See McCall v. Finley, 294 S.C. 1, 4, 362 S.E.2d 26,
  28 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œAppellate courts recognize . . . Â an overriding rule
  of civil procedure which says: whatever doesnâ€™t make any difference, doesnâ€™t
  matter.â€).
IV.Â Â Credit
Husband argues the
  family court erred in failing to reimburse him for the $16,000 he paid to Wife
  under the August 2004 separation agreement, which was later overturned by the
  family court. Â In Husbandâ€™s view, the $16,000 should be treated as an advance
  on the equitable distribution Wife received.Â  We disagree.Â  Â Â 
In support of his
  contention that he is entitled to a $16,000 credit, Husband submitted a
  document that listed his purported payments to Wife from August 2004 until
  January 2005.Â  However, Husband failed to include any checks, bills, or
  receipts that actually showed the amount he paid. Â Wife also testified that at
  most, she received two payments from Husband under the agreement.Â  Considering
  the family court found â€œHusbandâ€™s financial declaration and financial
  disclosures [were not] accurate depictions of his actual income and assets,â€ we
  find no credible evidence Husband actually paid Wife $16,000.Â  Further, the
  family court considered whether Husband was entitled to a $16,000 credit and
  specifically declined to give Husband any credit.Â  However, Husband did receive
  twenty percent more of the marital estate, a factor the family court most
  certainly considered when declining to give Husband a credit.Â  Therefore,
  because we affirm the overall apportionment of the marital property, we find no
  error in the family courtâ€™s failure to give Husband a credit.Â  See Deidun
    v. Deidun, 362 S.C. 47, 58, 606 S.E.2d 489, 495 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding on
  appeal, we look to the overall fairness of the apportionment, and if the end
  result is equitable, it is irrelevant if we would have arrived at a different
  apportionment).  
V. Transmutation
Husband argues the family court erred in concluding
  the residence where the parties lived during the marriage was transmuted into
  marital property.Â  Husband contends the land on which the marital residence was
  built was a gift from Simpson, Sr. and, therefore, his separate property.Â  We
  disagree.
In South Carolina, property acquired by either party during the marriage by gift from an
  individual other than the spouse is nonmarital property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-473(1).Â  Nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital
  property if: â€œ(1) it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be
  untraceable; (2) it is jointly titled; or (3) it is utilized by the parties in
  support of the marriage . . . so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make
  it marital property.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 98, 545 S.E.2d
  531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Pool v. Pool, 321 S.C. 84, 86, 467
  S.E.2d 753, 756 (Ct. App. 1996)). Â Whether transmutation
  of separate property into marital property has occurred â€œis a matter of intent
  to be gleaned from the facts of each case.â€ Â Johnson
    v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 295, 372 S.E.2d 107, 110 (Ct. App. 1988).
Although the
  evidence shows Husband acquired the land by gift from Simpson, Sr. during the
  marriage, the parties, using funds earned during the marriage, built the
  marital home.Â  Together, they cleared the land where the house was built.Â  The
  residence was occupied by both the parties from the time it was built in 1995
  until this action was commenced in 2004.Â  Clearly, the parties utilized the
  home and land in support of the marriage.Â  See Cooper v. Cooper,
  289 S.C. 377, 380, 346 S.E.2d 326, 328 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œAlthough the evidence
  shows that the husband acquired the land by gift from his father during the
  marriage, it also shows, and we so find, that the property lost its nonmarital
  character and therefore became subject to equitable distribution when the
  husband, nine years before the parties separated, erected the marital home
  thereon and thereby used the 1.4 acre tract in support of the marriage.â€).Â  Accordingly,
  we find the family court properly concluded the house was transmuted into
  marital property. Â Â 
VI.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Lastly, Husband argues the family court erred in
  awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â Â  He maintains he will be unable to
  pay the fees because he has less acreage to farm as a result of the equitable
  distribution.Â  He also claims Wife did not receive a beneficial result in the
  litigation.Â  We disagree.
Section
  20-7-420(38) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides, â€œSuit money,
  including attorneyâ€™s fees, may be assessed for or against a party to an action
  brought in or subject to the jurisdiction of the family court.â€Â  The award of
  attorneyâ€™s fees is within the sound discretion of the family court and absent
  an abuse of discretion, will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  In determining whether to award
  attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider â€œeach partyâ€™s ability to pay
  his or her own fee; the beneficial results obtained by the attorney; the
  partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and the effect of the fee on each
  partyâ€™s standard of living.â€Â  Id. (citing E.D.M. v. T.A.M, 307 S.C. 471, 476-77,
  415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992)).Â   
At
  the outset, we note Husband does not appeal the reasonableness of the fees and
  costs, but simply that he was ordered to pay half the fees.Â  Accordingly, we
  need not decide whether the fee amount was proper.Â  See State v. Hiott, 276 S.C. 72, 86, 276 S.E.2d 163, 170 (1981); Rule 208(b)(1)(B),
  (D), SCACR (stating an issue not argued in the brief is deemed abandoned and
  precludes consideration on appeal).
Â In
  the final order, the family court ordered Husband to pay half of Wifeâ€™s
  attorneyâ€™s fees and the cost of the certified public accountant for a total of
  $83,0391.91.Â  In his brief, Husband argues his acreage has been reduced, and he
  is responsible for the debt on the land the family court awarded Wife.Â 
  Therefore, he maintains he does not have a greater ability than Wife to pay
  fees.Â  However, Husband submitted no documentation to prove the land Wife
  received through equitable distribution is mortgaged.Â  The family court determined
  Wife was unlikely to be able to earn more than $25,000 a year, while Husband, a
  successful farmer, had the proven ability to earn $100,000 a year.[3]Â  In addition, Husband received twenty percent more of
  the marital estate.Â  We agree with the family court that because Husband was
  awarded substantially more assets, he will be able to pay the debts with less impact
  on his standard of living.
Further,
  the fact that Wife received a greater share of the marital estate after the
  separation agreement was set aside is evidence of Wifeâ€™s beneficial results.Â  Additionally,
  Husbandâ€™s lack of candor with the family court and failure to fully cooperate
  throughout the litigation process support an award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  See Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989) (finding
  the wife was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees and costs because â€œthe wifeâ€™s attorney
  faced difficulty and lack of cooperation from the husband, which serve[d] as an
  additional basis for the award of attorneysâ€™ feesâ€).Â  Therefore, because the
  family court fully examined the necessary factors in determining Wife was
  entitled to fees and costs, we can discern no abuse of discretion in the
  award.Â   
CONCLUSION
For the reasons
  stated above, the order of the family court is
AFFIRMED.[4]Â  
ANDERSON,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Husband was also a named party in Simpson, Sr.â€™s
  divorce.Â  See Simpson v. Simpson, Op. No. 2007-UP-147 (S.C. Ct. App. filed April, 4, 2007) (unpublished opinion). 
 
[2] At the hearing, both parties agreed Husband was to
  have custody of the two children.Â   
[3] Husbandâ€™s
  first financial declaration disclosed an income of $1,730.76 per month while
  his last disclosure to the court provided his income was $8,350 per month.Â  In
  concluding Husband had the ability to earn $100,000 in any given year, the
  family court also acknowledged Husbandâ€™s inconsistent declarations created
  difficulty in ascertaining Husbandâ€™s actual income.Â   
[4] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Ferguson
description: Nathaniel Ferguson, Jr., appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, alleging the trial court erred by denying his motion for a mistrial.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Nathaniel
      Kennedy Ferguson, Jr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Laurens County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 4342
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  20, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jerry
  W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Nathaniel
  Ferguson, Jr., appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a firearm
  during the commission of a violent crime, alleging the trial court erred by
  denying his motion for a mistrial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On the afternoon of May 13, 2004, Ferguson shot and killed
  Virginia Ann Wilson (Victim) following a dispute concerning repairs to water leaking
  inside Victimâ€™s home.Â  Victimâ€™s daughter, Kimberly Wilson (Girlfriend), is Fergusonâ€™s former girlfriend of ten years. Â Girlfriend and Ferguson have two daughters
  together and for the year preceding Victimâ€™s death, Girlfriend, Ferguson, their two daughters, and Fergusonâ€™s two children from a previous relationship had
  lived together in Girlfriendâ€™s mobile home.Â  Three weeks before Victimâ€™s death,
  Girlfriend and her two children moved next door into Victimâ€™s mobile home,
  while Ferguson and his children from the prior relationship remained in the
  first mobile homeÂ   
A common well and water line served the adjacent homes.Â  Immediately
  before the shooting, Girlfriendâ€™s father, George Earl, had attempted to repair
  a water leak inside Victimâ€™s home and had turned off the water supply serving
  both homes.[1]Â 
  During the repair, Earl asked someone to go out to the utility pole behind Victimâ€™s
  home to switch the water back on.Â  Victim volunteered, but before she went outside,
  she placed a loaded gun in the waistband of her pants.Â  While outside, Ferguson approached Victim to ask about the disruption to the water supply in his home. 
 
The subsequent events, which culminated in Victimâ€™s death, are disputed.Â 
  Ferguson contends he shot Victim in self-defense after she pointed and fired
  her gun at him.Â  Ferguson stated he ran toward Victim â€œin a zigzag pattern
  firing my gun.â€Â  However, Girlfriend testified Ferguson appeared agitated earlier
  that day.Â  She stated Ferguson began cursing at Victim before retrieving his
  gun from the car.Â  Girlfriend said she tried to get Victim to go back inside her
  house while Ferguson was retrieving his gun, but when Victim refused, Girlfriend
  went into Victimâ€™s home and called 911 for help.Â  Girlfriend testified Ferguson started shooting his gun at Victim as he walked toward Victimâ€™s yard.Â  Witness Gary
  Bryson testified he was driving by the Victimâ€™s residence when he heard a shot
  and saw Ferguson and Victim in the yard.Â  Bryson saw the Victim fall to the
  ground as Ferguson approached her with a gun in his hand.Â   
During the second day of trial, in response to a question about Fergusonâ€™s behavior at the time of the shooting, Girlfriend responded that Ferguson allegedly
  told her she â€œwas next.â€Â  Defense
  counsel asked the court to strike Girlfriendâ€™s response as unresponsive to the
  question asked.Â  Fergusonâ€™s counsel requested a mistrial, contending the court should strike Girlfriendâ€™s answer because
  the State did not notify the defense, in writing and during discovery, about Fergusonâ€™s alleged statement.Â  The court
  sustained Fergusonâ€™s objection, ruling Girlfriendâ€™s answer to the solicitorâ€™s
  question was unresponsive. Â However, the court denied Fergusonâ€™s motion for a
  mistrial, finding a curative instruction to the jury would overcome any
  potential prejudice to Ferguson. Â 
Ultimately, a jury found Ferguson guilty of murder and possession
  of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe decision to grant or deny a mistrial
  is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be overturned on
  appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.â€ Â State
    v. Edwards, 373 S.C. 230, 236, 644 S.E.2d 66, 69 (Ct. App. 2007). Â â€œThis Court favors the exercise of wide discretion of
  the trial court in determining the merits of [a mistrial] motion in each
  individual case.â€Â  State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 226, 522 S.E.2d
  845, 851 (Ct. App. 1999). Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Ferguson argues the trial court erred in denying his motion
  for a mistrial following Girlfriendâ€™s testimony that he told her she â€œwas nextâ€
  to be shot.Â  We disagree.  
The
  â€œ[g]ranting of a mistrial is a serious and extreme measure which should only be
  taken when the prejudice can be removed no other way. Â Generally, a curative
  instruction to disregard the testimony is deemed to have cured any alleged
  error.â€Â  State v. Edwards, 373 S.C. 230, 236, 644 S.E.2d 66, 69 (Ct. App.
  2007).Â  In Edwards, the appellant argued the trial court erred in
  denying his motion for a mistrial in his prosecution for criminal sexual
  misconduct with a minor because the jury improperly heard evidence he hit his
  wife.Â  Id.Â  We affirmed the trial court, finding (1) the prosecution had
  not intentionally elicited the statement; (2) the statement was not offered for
  its truth, but as â€œstate-of-mindâ€ evidence; and (3) any prejudice to Edwards
  was cured by the courtâ€™s curative instruction asking the jury to disregard the
  last statement given by the witness.Â  Id. at 236-37, 644 S.E.2d at 69; See
    also State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 227-28, 522 S.E.2d 845, 851 (Ct.
  App. 1999) (holding the trial court did not err in denying Patersonâ€™s motion
  for mistrial because an extensive curative instruction â€œcured any possible error and eliminated any conceivable prejudiceâ€).Â 
  Â 
Here, Fergusonâ€™s attorney asked Girlfriend on cross-examination about
  â€œwords [Ferguson] hadâ€ with her.Â  On redirect, the solicitor asked Girlfriend
  to discuss her observations of Fergusonâ€™s temperament prior to the shooting; Girlfriend
  testified Ferguson appeared â€œagitated.â€Â  Next, the solicitor asked Girlfriend:
  â€œ[W]hen you came outside and went to your mother, what was his behavior like
  then?â€Â  Girlfriend responded: â€œ[H]e was just standing there looking down at my [sic]
  mother at the time.Â  And when I exited the home at the same time the police was
  [sic] trying to get into the driveway.â€ Â The solicitor then asked: â€œDid he ever
  exhibit that behavior towards you?â€ Â Girlfriend responded: â€œYes, he exhibited
  [sic] towards me even when the police was there and they were ready to arrest
  him.Â  He looked at me and told me that I was next.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  

After dismissing the jury, the court heard from both sides on defense
  counselâ€™s objection to Girlfriendâ€™s answer.Â  The solicitor contended the
  defense opened the door by asking Girlfriend to discuss Fergusonâ€™s behavior,
  and that he had informed the defense about Fergusonâ€™s alleged comment a week
  earlier. Â He further alleged the testimony was admissible as evidence of Fergusonâ€™s state of mind immediately after he shot Victim.Â  The court ultimately sustained
  Fergusonâ€™s objection, and then heard arguments as to whether a curative
  instruction to the jury would be sufficient to counter potential prejudice to Ferguson. Â Both sides submitted cases to the court, and eventually it denied Fergusonâ€™s motion for a mistrial.Â  
 
When the jury returned to the courtroom, the court issued the
  following curative instruction:

	[S]ometimes when matters of law come up I am required to send you
  out of the courtroom because I may have to hear some testimony or hear some
  arguments that you donâ€™t need to hear so that I can make a ruling on those
  matters of law. Â . . . Â [B]efore th[e] break there was a question that was
  asked by the solicitor that was objected to by the defense attorney.Â  And I
  have sustained that objection on the grounds that the response that the witness
  gave to that question was not responsive, was not responding to the question
  that she was asked.Â  And I have made that ruling on the record and I would
  instruct you folks right now to forget about, ignore and disabuse from your
  mind the response that was given by the witness to the question that was asked
  prior to the break. Â It should not play any part in your fact finding function
  as a jury in this case. Â And so weâ€™re going to continue with the testimony at
  this time with those instructions to you . . . .Â  

We find the trial court properly exercised its
  discretion in deciding to give a curative instruction rather than granting Fergusonâ€™s motion for a mistrial.[2]Â 
  We additionally find the court cured any potential prejudice to Ferguson with its instruction to disregard Girlfriendâ€™s response to the question posed by
  the solicitor.Â  Here, as in Edwards, the trial courtâ€™s curative
  instruction was simple, and the court refrained from reiterating or emphasizing
  the unresponsive answer.Â  Accordingly, we find the instruction cured any potential
  prejudice, and we hold the trial court properly exercised its discretion in
  denying Fergusonâ€™s motion for a mistrial.  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Fergusonâ€™s convictions for
  murder and possession of a
  firearm during the commission of a violent crime are  
AFFIRMED.[3]  
KITTREDGE, J.,
  and THOMAS, J., concur.

[1] Detective Bolt testified Ferguson gave a statement to police the day after the shooting that Victim
  and Girlfriend disconnected the water line in order to annoy him.Â   
[2] We note that Ferguson made neither an overt
  contemporaneous objection as to the sufficiency of the curative instruction,
  nor a renewed motion for a mistrial after the court gave the jury the curative
  instruction.Â  See State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 510, 476 S.E.2d
  903, 912 (1996) (finding the issue is not preserved for review if the objecting
  party accepts the judgeâ€™s ruling and does not contemporaneously make an
  additional objection to the sufficiency of the curative charge or move for a
  mistrial). Â Rather, the following colloquy between the court and the attorneys
  ensued:

	Court:Â  [A]ny
  exceptions to [the curative] instruction from the state?
	Solicitor:Â 
  No, your Honor.
	Court:Â  Mr.
  Price? (Fergusonâ€™s Counsel)
	Fergusonâ€™s Counsel:Â  No, sir.
	Court:Â  Other
  than what you had already put on the record.
	Fergusonâ€™s Counsel:Â  That is correct.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
	

Because the additional
  statements between the court and Ferguson could be interpreted to satisfy the requirement
  of a contemporaneous objection, we have deemed the issue preserved for
  appellate review.
[3]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Franks
description: The issue in this appeal of a conviction for distribution of marijuana is whether the trial court should have issued a charge on the lesser-included offense of simple possession.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Michael James
      Franks, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Pickens County
Â G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4343
Submitted December 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  February 20, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia; for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and
  Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

THOMAS, J.:Â 
  Michael James Franks appeals his conviction for distribution of marijuana,
  contending the trial court erred in refusing to instruct the jury on the
  lesser-included offense of simple possession.Â  We affirm.[1]Â   
FACTS
On April 28, 2004, Agent Neysa Diana Caron
  of the Pickens County Sheriffâ€™s Department, accompanied by a confidential informant,
  went to a trailer at 36 Indian Creek Drive in Pickens County for the purpose of
  arranging an undercover buy.Â  When they reached the address, Caron noticed a
  woman at the window of the trailer facing their vehicle.Â  After the informant
  spoke with the woman, who was later identified as Heather Alley, Caron exited
  the vehicle, and someone admitted her and the informant into the trailer. Â Once
  inside the trailer, Caron and the informant went to a back bedroom, where they
  encountered Franks and Alley.
Franks,
  who was standing by a set of dresser drawers in the room, removed several bags
  of marijuana from a drawer and told Caron and the informant that the bags were
  â€œeach ounce bags.â€Â  Alley advised Caron and the informant that she had two
  quarter-ounce bags and inquired what they wanted.Â  When Caron answered she
  would buy a half ounce, Alley took the two bags, weighed them with hand-held
  scales, and asked Franks to â€œweigh these and make sure itâ€™s right.â€Â  After Alley
  tossed the bags to Franks, he weighed them, said â€œthey are fineâ€ and tossed
  them back to Alley.Â  When Alley gave Caron the marijuana, Caron asked the
  price, whereupon Franks answered it would be $60.00.Â  Caron then took $60.00
  and paid it to Alley, who counted the money and laid it on a bed in the room.Â 
 
Caron
  further testified that, when the informant asked about the possibility of
  buying a larger amount, it was Franks who answered the question.Â  Alley then
  wrote down both her own name and Franksâ€™s name, as well as their telephone
  numbers, on a piece of paper, which she gave to Caron.Â   
Franks
  and Alley were arrested some time after the sale[2] and charged with distribution of marijuana.Â  After a jury trial on September
  21, 2005, both were found guilty as charged.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn appellate
  court will not reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding jury instructions
  unless the trial court abused its discretion.â€Â  Clark v. Cantrell,
  339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs
  when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or, when grounded in
  factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.Â  Id.
â€œA trial judge is required to charge a jury on a lesser
  included offense if there is evidence from which it could be inferred that a
  defendant committed the lesser offense rather than the greater.â€Â  State v.
    Drafts, 288 S.C. 30, 32, 340 S.E.2d 784, 785 (1986).Â  Nevertheless, â€œdue
  process requires that a lesser included offense instruction be given only where
  the evidence warrants such an instruction.â€Â  Hopper v. Evans, 456 U.S. 605, 611 (1982).Â  â€œThe mere contention that the jury might accept the Stateâ€™s evidence
  in part and reject it in part is insufficient to satisfy the requirement that
  some evidence tend to show the defendant was guilty of only the lesser
  offense.â€Â  State v. Geiger, 370 S.C. 600, 608, 635 S.E.2d 669, 674 (Ct. App. 2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Franks argues on
  appeal the trial court erred in denying his request to instruct the jury that
  it could find him guilty of the lesser-included offense of simple possession of
  marijuana.Â  He contends the trial courtâ€™s agreement to charge mere presence to
  the jury supports an inference that, although Franks and Alley jointly
  possessed the marijuana, only Alley was the distributor.Â  We disagree.
The South Carolina
  Supreme Court has distinguished possession from mere presence, explaining that â€œproof of possession requires more than proof of mere
  presence, and . . . the State must show defendant had dominion and control over
  the thing allegedly possessed or had the right to exercise dominion and control
  over it.â€Â  State v. Tabory, 260 S.C. 355, 364-65, 196 S.E.2d 111, 113
  (1973).Â   
The
  evidence in the present case supporting the inference that Franks had dominion
  and control over the bags of marijuana that Caron purchased was as follows:Â 
  (1) Franks weighed the bags to be certain of the quantity that was being sold
  to Caron; (2) Franks tossed the bags back to Alley, who then immediately handed
  them to Caron; and (3) Franks himself told Caron how much she would have to pay
  for the drugs.Â  These acts, though probative of Franksâ€™s dominion and control
  of the marijuana Caron purchased, were also an integral part of the transaction
  that led to his arrest.Â  We cannot conceive of any way they would support a
  finding that Franks committed only the offense of possession of marijuana and
  did not participate in its distribution.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Caron explained that arrests are sometimes delayed
  for either additional investigation or protection of confidential informants.

title: Green Tree Servicing v. Williams
description: This case involves the issue of whether Lueveania Green's interest in property was subject to mortgages placed on the property by her granddaughter, who had held a fee simple determinable, after the property had reverted to Green.  it also involves Green's claim for trespass.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Green Tree
      Servicing, LLC as successor in interest to Conseco Finance Servicing Corp. as
      interest to Green Tree Financial Servicing Corporation, Plaintiff,
				v.
				Reniata L.
      Williams a/k/a Reniata Garvin Williams; Scott L. Williams, BB&T Bankcard
      Corporation; The South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles, Defendants,
				and
				Green Tree
      Servicing, LLC as successor in interest to Conseco Finance Servicing Corp. as
      interest to Green Tree Financial Servicing Corporation, Respondents,
				v.
				Lueveania
      Garvin, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Hampton County
Â Walter H. Sanders, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  4344
Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed February
  20, 2008

REVERSED AND REMANDED 
 


	
		
			
				Lueveania Garvin, for Appellant.
				Pearce W. Fleming, D. Randolph Whitt, and Martha S. Phillips, all of
  Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

HUFF, J.:Â 
  Lueveania Garvin appeals the order of the special referee holding her interest in
  certain property was subject and junior to Green Treeâ€™s mortgages and that she
  was not entitled to damages for trespass.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
In
  September of 1995, Garvin deeded .23 acres of property to her granddaughter, Reniata Williams.Â  The deed provided the property was to be used for
  residential purposes and further provided:

	In the event Reni[a]ta L. Garvin Williams shall fail to use said
  property for residential purposes for a consecutive period of sixty (60) days
  or more, the aforementioned property shall revert back to Grantor or Grantorâ€™s
  heirs and assigns, in fee simple.Â  

Thus,
  the interest Garvin transferred to Williams was a fee simple determinable while
  she retained a possibility of reverter.Â   
Williams
  subsequently obtained two notes secured by mortgages on the property.Â  Garvin
  was not a party to these mortgages.Â  Williams had a mobile home placed on the
  property.Â  The mobile home encroached onto Garvinâ€™s property by six feet.Â 
 
On June 1, 2004, Williams wrote to Garvin that she no longer
  resided on the property and in recognition of the condition in the deed, she
  wished to return the property to Garvin.Â   
Green Tree then brought this action for foreclosure of the
  mortgages in August of 2004.Â  In an order filed December 30, 2004, the special
  referee ordered foreclosure of the mortgages.Â  Garvin was not named a party to
  the action at this time.Â  In April of 2005 Garvin wrote to Green Tree stating
  she would charge it $25.00 a day storage fee effective June 1, 2004 for the
  mobile home on her property.Â  She explained $10.00 a day was for the part of
  the mobile home on the far end of her yard previously deeded to Williams and
  $15.00 a day was for the part of the mobile home that extended into her front yard.Â  
 
Green
  Tree subsequently filed a petition for a rule to show cause requesting the
  court order Garvin to show cause why she should not be bound by the previous
  order and determine whether Garvinâ€™s interest was junior to Green Treeâ€™s
  mortgages.Â  The court issued the rule as requested.Â  Garvin answered
  asseverating Green Tree executed the mortgages with knowledge of the
  possibility of reverter.Â  She also asserted a claim for trespass.Â   
After a
  hearing on the matter, the special referee held Garvin had no estate in the
  property until the possibility of reverter was triggered, which was after Green
  Tree had perfected its mortgage.Â  Thus, the referee held Garvinâ€™s interest in
  the property was subject and junior to Green Treeâ€™s mortgage that was already
  in place when she acquired an estate in the property.Â  In addition, the referee
  held that as Garvin had submitted no evidence of any diminution in the market
  value of her property due to the mobile homeâ€™s presence on her property, she
  was not entitled to damages for trespass.Â  However, the referee did order Green
  Tree to remove the trailer from Garvinâ€™s property.Â  This appeal followed.Â 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.  Mortgages
Garvin
  argues the special referee erred in holding her interest in the property was
  subject to and junior to Green Treeâ€™s mortgages.Â  We agree.Â   
A fee simple determinable is a grant that can be cut short
  when a given term expires.Â  Scott v. Brunson, 351 S.C. 313, 316, 569
  S.E.2d 385, 387 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œIt is an estate in fee â€˜with a qualification
  annexed to it by which it is provided that it must determine whenever that
  qualification is at an endâ€™â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Parks, Recreation, & Tourism
    v. Brookgreen Gardens, 309 S.C. 388, 392, 424 S.E.2d 465, 467 (1992)
  (quoting Purvis v. McElveen, 234 S.C. 94, 98, 106 S.E.2d 913, 915 (1959)).Â 
  The wording of the grant allows for defeasance of the grantee upon the terms,
  covenants and conditions of the grant.Â  Brookgreen Gardens, 309 S.C. at 392, 424 S.E.2d at 467.Â  A possibility of reverter is the future
  interest that accompanies a fee simple determinable.Â  Id.Â  In the case of a possibility of reverter, the possessory estate vests
  immediately and automatically upon the happening of the event whereby the
  determinable or conditional fee is terminated.Â  Batesburg-Leesville Sch.
    Dist. No. 3 v. Tarrant, 293 S.C. 442, 446, 361 S.E.2d 343, 346 (Ct. App.
  1987).Â   
Although
  the grantee of a fee simple determinable may transfer or assign the estate, the
  determinable quality of the estate follows the transfer or assignation.Â  28
  Am.Jur. 2nd Estates Â§ 30 (2000).Â  The determinable fee may be
  mortgaged, subject to the qualification.Â  27 S.C. Jur. Mortgages Â§ 19(e)
  (1996).Â  The creator of the estate would have to join in the mortgage to
  subject the entire fee interest to the lien.Â  Id.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The deed granting
  Williams the fee simple determinable estate was duly recorded and was referred
  to in the mortgage.Â  Green Tree was on notice of the nature of the estate.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-9-30 (2007) (stating recording of instrument is notice to
  all persons, sufficient to put them upon inquiry of the purport of the filed
  instrument and the property affected by the instrument); Binkley v. Rabon
    Creek Watershed Conservation Dist., 348 S.C. 58, 71, 558 S.E.2d 902, 909
  (Ct. App. 2001) (stating notice of a deed is notice of its whole contents).Â 
  Garvin never joined in the mortgages and the mortgages were subject to the
  determinable quality of the estate.Â  When the determinable fee was terminated,
  Green Treeâ€™s interest in the property terminated.Â  Therefore, the special
  referee erred in holding Garvinâ€™s interest in the property was subject to Green
  Treeâ€™s mortgages.Â   
2.  Trespass
Garvin
  argues the special referee erred in holding her claim for trespass failed as
  she had not established a diminution in the market value of the property due to
  placement of the mobile home on her property.Â  We agree.Â   
If a plaintiff
  establishes a willful trespass, the damages from invasion of the plaintiffâ€™s
  legal rights will be presumed sufficient to sustain the action even though such damages may be only nominal and not capable of
  measurement.Â  Hinson v. A. T. Sistare Construction Co., 236 S.C. 125,
  113 S.E.2d 341, 344 (1960). Â Thus, Garvin did not need to establish a
  diminution in value to her property to maintain her claim for trespass.Â  We
  reverse the order of the special referee and remand the trespass claim for
  further proceedings.Â   
CONCLUSION
We reverse the
  special refereeâ€™s holding that Garvinâ€™s interest in the property was subject
  and junior to Green Treeâ€™s mortgages.Â  We further reverse the special refereeâ€™s
  ruling on Garvinâ€™s trespass claim and remand for further proceedings consistent
  with this opinion.Â   
REVERSED AND
  REMANDED
PIEPER, J., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Atkins v. Horace Mann Insurance
description: Clifford Atkins appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding Horace Mann Insurance Company (Horace Mann) made him a commercially reasonable offer of underinsured motorist (UIM) coverage, and that the underlying policy should not be reformed to include UIM coverage up to liability limits.  Atkins contends Horace Mann failed to meet its burden of proving that a meaningful offer of UIM coverage was made.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Clifford A.
      Atkins, Appellant,
				v.
				Horace Mann
      Insurance Company Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Barnwell County
Doyet A. Early,III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4345
Heard December 12, 2007 â€“ Filed February
  21, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				E.T. Moore, Jr. and Angela W. Abstance, both of Barnwell, for
  Appellant.
				Karl Brehmer and L. Darby Plexico, III, both of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Clifford
  Atkins appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding Horace Mann Insurance Company
  (Horace Mann) made him a commercially reasonable offer of underinsured motorist
  (UIM) coverage, and that the underlying policy should not be reformed to
  include UIM coverage up to liability limits.Â  Atkins contends Horace Mann
  failed to meet its burden of proving that a meaningful offer of UIM coverage
  was made.Â  We affirm.Â   
FACTS
On or about
  December 27, 2000, Atkins purchased a 1993 Lexus.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order is
  contradictory as to the manner in which Atkinsâ€™ Lexus became covered by Horace
  Mann.Â  The order initially states â€œthe plaintiff purchased a policy of
  Insurance covering the [new] Lexus.â€Â  However, the next paragraph states Atkins
  made a request â€œto add the Lexus to his existing Horace Mann policy . . . â€ After
  making this request, Kevin Hunt, a new agent for Horace Mann, sent Atkins a form
  entitled â€œAutomobile coverage selection/ rejection form.â€Â  Atkinsâ€™ name, date,
  policy number, and the make and model of his new Lexus were already filled in
  at the top of the form.Â  Just below this information, in a section titled
  â€œUninsured and Underinsured Motor Vehicle Coverage Offers,â€ the form instructed
  Atkins to â€œplease check the limits you want for each coverage and sign and date
  your choice.Â  You must sign your name five times on this form.â€Â  Immediately
  below this instruction, the form indicated that Atkinsâ€™ existing policy
  liability limits were $100,000/ $300,000/ $50,000.  
Under
  the heading entitled â€œUnderinsured Motor Vehicle Bodily Injury Coverage,â€ seven
  choices of coverage were listed, ranging from $15,000/$30,000 to
  $500,000/$1,000,000.Â  A check mark on the form indicates Atkins chose UIM
  coverage in the amount of $25,000/$50,000.Â  This selection was below his policy
  liability limits, but is the same amount of UIM coverage he had on his other
  cars insured with Horace Mann.Â  Atkins admits he signed his name on the
  signature line under the UIM section; however, Atkins contends he does not
  recall writing the date beside the signature line or putting a check mark for
  the levels of UIM coverage that were selected.Â  Atkins also admits that he
  signed his name under the acknowledgment paragraph, indicating he had read the
  explanations and offers of UM and UIM coverage.Â   
On October 22,
  2003, Atkins was involved in an automobile accident with Terry Gillyard, and
  suffered bodily injuries and other damages.Â  Gillyardâ€™s insurance company
  tendered its liability limits to Atkins, but Atkins sought additional compensation
  from Horace Mann because his damages exceeded Gillyardâ€™s coverage limits.Â 
  Thereafter, Atkins filed a declaratory judgment action requesting to have his
  policy with Horace Mann reformed to provide him with UIM coverage equal to the
  limits of his liability insurance coverage.Â   
The
  circuit court found Horace Mann was not entitled to the conclusive presumption
  of a meaningful offer pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-350(B) (Supp. 2007).Â  This
  finding has not been appealed and therefore is
  not before us for review. See Dreher v. Dreher, 370 S.C. 75, 78
  n.1, 634 S.E.2d 646, 647 n.1 (2006) ( â€œ[A]n unappealed ruling becomes the law of the case
  and precludes further consideration of the issue on appeal
  [.]â€) (citing In re Morrison, 321 S.C. 370, 372 n.2, 468 S.E.2d 651, 652
  n.2 (1996)).Â  The circuit court ultimately ruled in favor of Horace Mann,
  concluding Horace Mann had carried its burden of proving that it had made a
  meaningful offer of UIM coverage to Atkins pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  38-77-160 (2002) and Â§ 38-77-350 (Supp. 2007), and the Wannamaker Test.[1]Â 
  Atkins appeals this ruling, asserting the circuit court erred in holding that
  Horace Mann carried its burden of proving it made a meaningful offer to
  Atkins.Â  We disagree.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A
  suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined
  by the nature of the underlying issue.Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160,
  164, 631 S.E.2d 539, 541 (2006).Â  In this case, the underlying issue involves
  determination of coverage under an insurance policy, and therefore, is an
  action at law.Â  Auto-Owners Ins. Co., v. Hamin, 368 S.C. 536, 540, 629
  S.E.2d 683, 685 (Ct. App. 2006) (cert. granted 2007).Â  In an action at law,
  tried without a jury, the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed
  on appeal unless a review of the record reveals there is no evidence which
  reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v.
    Calcutt, 340 S.C. 231, 237, 530 S.E.2d 896, 899 (Ct. App. 2000).  
LAW/ ANALYSIS
We initially note that the addition of Atkinsâ€™ Lexus
  to his Horace Mann policy appears to be a â€œâ€˜changeâ€™ to an existing policy as
  contemplated by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-350(C) (Supp. 2007), and thus a new
  offer of UIM coverage is not mandated.â€ Smith v. South Carolina Ins. Co.,
  350 S.C. 82, 88-89, 564 S.E.2d 358, 362 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In Smith, this
  court held that â€œ[a]n insurer is not required to make a new offer of UIM
  coverage when an insured adds an additional vehicle to an existing automobile
  insurance policy.â€Â  Id. at 89, 564 S.E.2d at 362.Â  However, since Horace
  Mann made an offer of UIM coverage to Atkins, this offer must be a meaningful
  offer pursuant to the statute and Wannamaker.Â  Wannamaker at 521,
  354 S.E.2d at 556.Â  We find Horace Mann made a valid offer and therefore
  affirm.Â   
Section 38-77-160
  of the South Carolina Code (2002) provides automobile insurers must â€œoffer at
  the option of the insured, underinsured motorist coverage up to the limits of
  the insured liability coverage.â€Â  To comply with this statutory obligation, the
  insurerâ€™s offer of UIM coverage must be â€œmeaningful.â€Â  Tucker v. Allstate
    Ins. Co., 337 S.C. 128, 130, 522 S.E.2d 819, 820 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The
  insurer bears the burden of establishing that it made a meaningful offer.Â  Butler v. Unisun Ins. Co., 323 S.C. 402, 405, 475 S.E.2d 758, 759 (1996).Â  If
  the insurer fails to comply with its statutory duty to make a meaningful offer
  to the insured, the policy will be reformed by operation of law to include UIM
  coverage up to the limits of liability insurance carried by the insured.Â  Id., at 404, 475 S.E.2d at 760.Â  
 
Atkins maintains
  Horace Mannâ€™s offer failed the Wannamaker test in two respects.Â  First, Atkins
  asserts the offer was not made in a commercially reasonable manner because Hunt
  never spoke with him directly, instead mailing him a selection/rejection form.Â 
  We disagree.Â  The use of mail is a reasonable method of communicating with the
  insured about an important business transaction.Â  Dewart v. State Farm Mut.
    Auto. Ins. Co., 296 S.C. 150, 153-54, 370, S.E.2d 914, 917 (Ct. App.
  1988).Â Â  Moreover, Atkins had an ongoing relationship with Horace Mann when he
  purchased the Lexus.Â  He chose to call Hunt to insure his Lexus instead of
  going by the agentâ€™s office, and it was apparently acceptable to him to read
  the automobile coverage selection/rejection form, sign every blank, and return
  it to the agent via the mail.Â  Therefore, we find that the Horace Mannâ€™s
  notification process was commercially reasonable.
Next, Atkins
  contends that Horace Mann failed to intelligibly advise him of the nature of
  underinsured motorist coverage.Â  Again, we disagree.Â  Atkins purchased exactly
  the same UIM coverage for his Lexus that he had previously purchased on all his
  other vehicles insured by Horace Mann.Â  In addition, Atkins properly signed the
  form in the five required locations, including the lines accepting UIM coverage
  at limits of 25/50 and under the paragraph acknowledging he had read the form
  in its entirety.Â  The form clearly explains the nature of UIM coverage:Â 
  various options of UIM coverage limits are set out, every appropriate selection
  is made, each signature block is signed, and the form adequately explains where
  the insured is to seek out additional information if he or she has questions.Â  Moreover,
  Atkins is a high school teacher, former principal, and coach of thirty-five
  years with a Masterâ€™s degree and over thirty hours towards a PhD. Â Â 
Atkins
  relies heavily on Floyd v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. to claim Horace Mann
  did not intelligibly advise him of the nature of underinsured coverage.Â  Floyd
    v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 367 S.C. 253, 626 S.E.2d 6 (2005).Â  However,
  the holding in Floyd was limited to the issue of whether Nationwide was
  entitled to the conclusive presumption of a meaningful offer of UIM coverage
  pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-350(B) (Supp. 2007).Â  Id.Â  As
  mentioned above, that issue it not before us for review, and therefore Floyd is not controlling.Â  Accordingly, we find that Horace Mann intelligibly advised
  Atkins of the nature of underinsured coverage.[2]Â   
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the circuit courtâ€™s order is  
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, J.,
  and THOMAS, J., concur.

[1] To determine whether an insurer has complied with its
  duty to offer optional coverages and thus make a meaningful offer of UIM
  coverage, the court must consider the following factors:Â  (1) the insurerâ€™s
  notification process must be commercially reasonable, whether oral or in
  writing; (2) the insurer must specify the limits of optional coverage and not
  merely offer additional coverage in general terms; (3) the insurer must
  intelligibly advise the insured of the nature of the option coverage: and (4)
  the insured must be told that optional coverages are available for an
  additional premium.Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Wannamaker, 291
  S.C. 518, 521, 354 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1987).
[2] We note that Atkins does not challenge factors (2)
  and (4) of the Wannamaker test; nevertheless, we address those briefly.Â 
  The selection/rejection form adequately specified the limits of optional
  coverage, and the form also adequately explained that optional coverages were
  available for an additional premium.Â  Butler at 405, 475 S.E.2d at 759.
